Tuesday, May 5, 1868.
  Clear and a pleasant day.
We had no school to day,
as it was Coll. exhibition.
Ther. about 50[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 60[degrees].
Rose at 4 A.M. and went
shooting into the Snipe
Swamp. Shot two Vir.
Rails (one flying) and
a female Sora. Met
Rodgers in the swamp
& hunted with him
for some time. He
shot a Vir. Rail.
Billy pointed two
Rails. Got back at 9 A.M.
Then up to Waverly in shooting
wagon with Henshaw. Saw during
the day Towhees, Br. Thrushes,
Ch. Sid. Warb, Nash. War.
Blk. Th. Green War. Water
Thrush & House Wren.
in evening stuffed a sing.
Swamp Sp. shot this A.M.
& the Rail.
Wednesday, May 6, 1868.
  Clear and a pleasant
day. Ther. about 50[degrees] - 
60[degrees] - 45[degrees]. Rose as
usual and exercised my
dogs. After lunch studied
at the R's as usual.
Then at 3 P.M. took
Billy and went shooting
with R. Deane. First half
around 'the pond'. Fired
at a Kingfisher. Then
fired at a Cliff Swallow.
Then shot a Chipping
Sparrow with one white
tail feather. Then R. Deane
shot a Chimney & Brown
Swallow. Came home
around 'the pond'.
R. Deane shot a male
Blue Yellow Backed Warbler.
In evening finished the
Rail stuffed last night &
stuffed the Chippy.

Thursday, May 7, 1868.
  Cloudy. Rained most 
of P.M. Ther. about
50[degrees] - 65[degrees] - 50[degrees].
Rose as usual.
After lunch in P.M.
studied about two
hours with Theo.
Then rode down with
him and got some
tar & tin for our boat.
After dinner went
up to 'the pond'. Went
through the Pine Swamp
& saw two Night Herons.
Shot a male Carolina
Rail flushing him
soon after he stopped
singing. At least a dozen
male Soras were singing
in the Snipe Swamp.
Friday, May 8, 1868.
  A.M. cloudy. P.M.
Cloudy. Ther. about
34[degrees] - 40[degrees] - 36[degrees].
Had quite a snow storm
this morning. Rose as
usual and exercised my
dogs. After lunch went
up to Waverly in the shooting
wagon with R. Deane.
First up through the Willows.
Shot a Rabit from the wagon
and a Robin. Ruth shot a
Cat Bird & a Blk & Wh. Creeper.
Then fired several times at Cliff
Swallows & saw a Snipe.
A man accused us of shooting
his ducks. Then around into
Waltham & shot a male Towhee
& a female Warbler unknown
to me. Got home at 7 P.M.
In evening stuffed the
male Rail shot last night.

Saturday, May 9, 1868.
  Clear and pleasant.
Ther. about 50[degrees] - 66[degrees] - 50[degrees].
Rose at 3.30 A.M. & R. Deane
joined me. We intended to
dig out a Kingfisher's nest
could not find the hole. Shot
two Least Pewees but spoilt one.
Took Jack. At Belmont crossing
heard a Yl. Thrt. Vireo. In Waverly
woods on the Eastern side fired
at Br. Thrush, shot female Bl. & Wh.
Creeper, female Towhee, Rabbit,
Solitary Vireo, (heard Gl. Cr. Thrush
& fired at one), Gray Squirrell,
Wood Thrush (male), Robin,
Rose Br. Grosbeak (young male).
Then started home across the fields
shot a female Albino Robin, &
three Rusties at a shot. Charlie Deane
carried us home. In P.M. stuffed the
al. Robin, unknown Warbler, Sol.
Vireo, & Bl. & W. Creeper. In evening
the fe. Gr. Robin. R. Deane shot f. Rusty
Towhee, Blk. & Wh. Creeper, Gl. Cr. Thrush
Sol. Vireo, &
Sunday, May 10, 1868.
  A.M. warm & pleasant
P.M. cloudy with East
wind. Ther. about 50[degrees] - 
65[degrees] - 50[degrees]. Rose as usual
& shaved. Attended church
in A.M. In P.M.
took a ride with father
& just before we started
Bob Smith called to see
my dogs & was very much
taken  by Jup. In our
ride saw a King Bird.
Went over to South Reading
& coming home saw a
yellow & white Pointer.
Wrote most of evening.
On the way to church
heard a Warbling Vireo. Many
of the buds are opening into
leaf but the season has been very
backward. Had asparagus
to day for the first time.
The grass is several inches
high.

Monday, May 11, 1868.
  Clear but with Easterly
wind. Ther. about 42[degrees] - 
55[degrees] - 35[degrees]. Rose
as usual and exercised
the dogs. Walked down
to school with Theo.
After lunch Dan came
out & took dinner with
us. Began having dinner
at 3 P.M. to day.
After dinner Dan
& I took Tiger in the
open buggy & taking
R. Deane in rode up
to Waltham where Dan
took the cars. Then
rode back with Ruth.
As soon as we get back
father cut the end of
Jup's tail off spoiling
his good looks: it bled
all the evening. Went
to bed at 9.30 P.M.
Tuesday, May 12, 1868.
  Clear and a lovely
day. Ther. About 45[degrees] - 
65[degrees] - 42[degrees]. Rose at
5.30 A.M. & went
up to the R's & studied
my Greek with Theo.
After I got back from
school put up a bird
box & a powder keg.
Then took my blow gun
and shot a male House
Wren. In P.M. stuffed
the Least Pewee & Rose Breasted
Grosbeak and in the
evening the House Wren.
In the latter part of P.M.
R. Deane came down:
He saw a Bal. Oriole
to day. The lilac bushes
are covered with leaves & I
saw the first Cherry blossoms
to day. Stuffed during the
afternoon with the window
open.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Wednesday, May 13, 1868.
  Cloudy all day.
Began to rain at 3 P.M.
and rained the rest
of the day and
evening. Ther. about
45[degrees] - 50[degrees] - 50[degrees].
Rose at 5.30 A.M.
and studied my
Greek with Theo.
Read for about an
hour after getting back
from school. In P.M.
practised with my
blow gun and fixed
some of my birds.
In evening, stuffed
the male Wood Thrush
shot Saturday.
Thursday, May 14, 1868.
  A.M. cloudy. P.M.
clear. Ther. about 45[degrees] - 
70[degrees] - 60[degrees]. Rose as
usual and exercised
the dogs. Attended school
as usual. After lunch
took Tiger and had a
horseback ride through
Belmont, Waverly,
Lexington & Waltham.
Saw numbers of Bal. Orioles
& watched a Prairie Warbler
for some time. Heard
a Bittern in the Lex
willows. Dug open
a fresh Downy Woodpecker's
hole but it contained
nothing. Saw a Woodchuck.
Got back at 6.30 P.M.
Then Farrar came in
and spent about an hour
with me. Put up a
bird box.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Friday, May 15, 1868.
  Cloudy all day. Did
not rain much
in A.M. but poured
all the afternoon.
Had a return of
the weak side that
I had last Spring &
was obliged to ride
down to school.
Rode home also.
Saw several Hum.
Birds and watched
a male chasing a 
Chipping Sparrow.
In P.M. rode down
to the Port and bought
twelve hip boxes, six of which
I brought home in my
buggy. Then went
to the Gas House and
got a kettle of tar.
Saw a boat there which
I think of buying.
Jack began to be sick 
to day.
Saturday, May 16, 1868.
  Cloudy. Rained several
times. Ther. about 50[degrees] - 
65[degrees] - 50[degrees]. Rose at
5.30 A.M., R. Deane
waking me by throwing
pebbles against my window.
Immediately rose and took
Tiger in the shooting wagon.
Rode first up into Waltham
where Ruth shot a Rabbit. Then
further on we both shot two
male Prairie Warblers. I shot a male
Pine Creeping Warbler & R. a female
Touhee in the act of building & a Nashville
Warbler. Then into Lexington;
I shot a Roscoes Yellow Throat (male),
Red Eyed Vireo (spoilt him),
two male Gl. Cr. Thrushes (spoilt
one). R. shot a male R. Br. Gros-
beak. Then down through Belmont
shot a male Bittern in "the
Willows". Watched him"pumping"
for some time before I fired. Got back at 12 N.
In P.M. & evening stuffed the two
Prairie Warblers, the Rose Yellow Throat
& the Pine Creeping.

occurrenceRemarks:
Sunday, May 17, 1868.
  A.M.clear. P.M.
cloudy with East wind.
Ther. about 60[degrees] - 75[degrees] - 
50[degrees].  Rose as usual
and exercised the
dogs. Attended
church as usual.
In P.M. rode up
to Concord with
father & saw the
Frenches. On the
way up saw a
female Red Start.
Jack was very sick
to day and drank
a great deal of water.
Monday, May 18, 1868.
  Cloudy and rained
most of the day.
Ther. about 50[degrees] - 60[degrees] - 
50[degrees]. Rose as usual
& let out my dogs.
Rode down to school
as my side is rather
weak. Studied as soon
as I got home from
school & Jim Crosswell
studied with us.
In P.M. stuffed the
male Bittern as far
as putting in the eyes.
Then went down to the
Gas House with R. Deane
& bought a boat for
$10.00. The pear trees are in
full blossom also the plum &
peach trees. The apple trees are
covered with leaves & it is
impossible to see through the
horse chestnut & lilac trees
so thick are the leaves. Jack
is about the same. Finished
the Bittern this evening.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Tuesday, May 10, 1868.
  Poor Jack is very weak.
Cloudy but did not
rain. Ther. about
55[degrees] - 65[degrees] - 50[degrees].
Rose as usual and
exercised the dogs.
Walked down to school
with Theo and Ed.
Studied immediately after
lunch which I had
at 2 P.M. Then took
my wagon & with E. 
Dodge & R. Deane, rode
up to Belmont. On the
way up called in to see
Bruce & arranged about
keeping our boat there.
Then went into Mr. Ch.
barn & saw his African
sheep. Got some dog tooth
violets at Waverly.
R. Deane climbed up to
what we thought was a
Hawk's nest. One of my
Swallows had an egg.
Father gave Jack some brandy.
Wednesday, May 20, 1868.
  Jack died at about
1 P.M.
Cloudy all day. Began
to rain at about 2 P.M.
& rained hard the rest
of the day. Ther. about
50[degrees] - 60[degrees] - 50[degrees].
Rose as usual and,
exercised the dogs. Visited
Jack who was very
weak. Also cut the holes
in some bird boxes.
Went in to see Jack when
I got back from school
and found him dead.
In P.M. went down to
the Gas House and brought
our boat up in the hay
rigging. The blossoms
are falling off the
cherry trees. The pear
trees are nearly all out.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Thursday, May 21, 1868.
  Saw a Hummingbird.
Cloudy all day. Rained
hard most of the time.
Ther. about 50[degrees] - 55[degrees] - 
52[degrees]. We have had so
much water lately that
all the meadows are
flooded. Rose as usual
and exercised the dogs.
Got quite wet going
down to school.
Rode home as it was
raining very hard.
After lunch studied
about two hours at
the Russell's. Then
William & I buried
Jack under the apple
tree. R. Deane came
down while we were
burying him. Also made
a bird box. Read most
of the evening. Some of the
apple trees are blossomed out
& the linden trees are
getting green.
Friday, May 22, 1868.
  A.M. cloudy & rained
a good deal. Ther.
about 50[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 65[degrees].
Cleared off about 2 P.M.
and we had the first
pleasant afternoon that
we have had for a long
time. Rose as usual.
Got dismissed at recess.
Jim Crosswell & Washy
came up with me and
we rode up to Waverly in
the shooting wagon. Got
a number of violets & found
a Sp. Sandpiper's with one
egg & a Song Sparrow's with
four. Then on to the Willow's.
Heard a Night Hawk & a Common
Rail & saw a Virginian Rail.
Found a Chickadee's with seven
eggs which we took home
stump & all. Got back at 3.30 P.M.
In P.M. fixed our boat with
R. Deane. Put up four boxes.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Saturday, May 23, 1868.
  Cloudy & rained the greater
part of the day. Rose
at 4 A.M. & found R.
Deane waiting for me.
We called Bill & soon
got off in the wagon.
First tied the horse in a
pine grove in Waltham.
I shot three Blk. Poll Warbler's,
an albino Field Sparrow (a male
having a white tail feather),
a female Field Sparrow; R.
Deane found a Field Sparrow's
with 4 fresh eggs. Then went
on to Lexington. Here I shot
a King Bird, a Scarlet Tanager
(male), a Nashville Warbler (female),
a Redstart (female), & a Red
Eyed Vireo, male. Found a
Crows nest with 4 young & brought
two home but they died on the way.
R. Deane saw & fired at a Cape May
War., a Blk. Thrt. Blue Warb, & 4 Turt.
Doves. Saw an Indigo Bird.
In P.M. & evening stuffed the Redstart,
Field Sparrows, Nash. Warb. & a male Blk. Poll.
Sunday, May 24, 1868.
  Cloudy & rained most
of the day. Ther.
about 50[degrees] - 55[degrees] - 
50[degrees]. Attended
church in A.M.
as usual. In P.M.
took a walk with
R. Deane up around
'the pond' & saw a female
Blue Yellow Backed
Warbler.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Monday, May 25, 1868.
  Cloudy as usual and
rained a number of times.
We are having a remarkably
long spell of dull weather.
Rose as usual. After breakfast
took my wagon & called for J.
Crosswell. We rode first up
to the Willows where I shot
a male Delafields, a female Blue
Yellow Backed Warbler & a Wilson's
Black Cap. Saw a swamp
Sparrow & a Virginia Rail
building. Then up the road
about Â½ of a mile & across towards
Lexington. Saw Woodcock
with three young, one of 
which I took. Got back at
about 2 P.M. In P.M. stuffed
the Blue Yl. Back, the female Nashville
(shot Saturday), the Delafield's, & the
young Woodcock. In the evening
stuffed the Red Eyed Vireo (shot Sat)
& saw E. Dodge in reference to
to morrow's excursion.
Tuesday, May 26, 1868.
  Cloudy & rained most of the day.
Rose at 4.30 A.M. and
went shooting with E. Dodge
in the wagon. First tied
the horse on the hill near
the Waltham pine woods & went
into the Woods near 'the Willows'.
Shot a female Chestnut Side,
& a female White Eyed Vireo. Pushed
over a stump & got five eggs from 
it.: shot the male Downy but
spoilt him. Coming back to the
wagon found a Towhee's with two
& saw a Delafield building. Then
further into Waltham. Found
a Field Sparrow's with four fresh.
Then into Lexington. Then down
through the Willows & shot a female
Maryland Yellow Throat. Found
a Swamp Sparrow's with five &
shot the old bird. In the P.M. stuffed
Sc. Tanager & King Bird shot Sat, also
female White Eye & female Chestnut
Sided Warbler.

occurrenceRemarks:
Wednesday, May 27, 1868.
  First part of A.M. cloudy
& misty. Cleared off at
about 10 A.M.
Ther. about 50[degrees] - 70
65[degrees]. Rose as usual.
Trained the dogs for about
an hour. Then took my
blow gun & spent several
hours in the garden firing
at small birds. At last
shot a female Warbling Vireo.
Then stuffed the female
Maryland Yellow Thrt. shot
yesterday and skinned
a White Eyed Vireo (female
shot yesterday). In P.M.
rode up to the Md. Lark's
nest in Waverly with Ruth
& got him eggs of which I had
three. Then rode down to
arrange about Henshaw's
going egging to morrow.
In evening attended theatricals
at the Wyman's and was
introduced to Miss Parker.
Thursday, May 28, 1868.
  First part of A.M. cloudy.
Rest of day clear & beautiful.
Rose at 5 A.M. & found H. Henshaw
waiting for me. Had Tiger
harnessed and rode over to
Stoneham. First found a Blue
Jay's with five rather fresh eggs.
Then shot a male Indigo Finch.
Then went up a high rocky
hill & shot a Night Hawk flying.
Saw a pair of Whip Poor Wills
& fired at one. Got a number of 
violets. Then down to the shore
of Spot Pond & found a Wood
Thrush's built in a pine tree &
containing three eggs, then a Hum.
Birds newly finished, then at a
Cooper's Hawk's with five about
five days old, the bird flew off when
we got under the tree. Then shot a Blk.
Th. Green, a male Chest. Side, &
another Night Hawk. Coming back
through Wobern got home at 2 P.M.
In P.M. stuffed the Indigo Bird
& Warbling Vireo.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Friday, May 29, 1868.
  A.M. clear. P.M.
cloudy. Ther. about
60[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 65[degrees].
Rose as usual and
exercised the dogs after
breakfast. Then stuffed
a male Night Hawk
shot yesterday & also
a male Blk. Thrt. Green
Warbler. Was just finishing
the latter when Dan
came. Started at 3 P.M.
& rode up to Concord
with him. Put
the horse in the stables of
the Middlesex Hotel.
Read and talked most
of the evening.
Saturday, May 30, 1868.
  The first still day that
we have had for some
time. Ther. About  50[degrees] - 60[degrees] - 
60[degrees]. A.M. cloudy. Rained
hard in the latter part
of P.M. Got up at 7 A.M.
& carried Dan's grandfather
to the depot. Then took the
boat and sailed up to
Fairhaven Bay. Found a
Phoebe's nest fastened on a
rock and ready for the eggs.
Found seven or eight Red
Wings containing more
or less eggs all fresh. Went
ashore & Dan shot a R. Breast
Grosbeak with my gun. Found
a Mottled Owls nest in a
Woodpecker's hole with 4 young
& the old Owl - a red one - on.
Took two young ones. Took
a young crow also from
its nest containing 5. Rode
about Concord in P.M. Dan
stuffed his Grosbeak in the evening.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Sunday, May 31, 1868.
  Clear and the first
pleasant day that we
have had for some
time. Ther. about 60[degrees] - 
72[degrees] - 65[degrees]. Rose at
about 5 A.M. In A.M.
walked down to the
river & saw several
Wilson's Black Caps and
quantities of Black Poll
Warblers. At 2 P.M.
got my horse & came
home, Dan riding down
to Walden with me.
Here I took a bath and
saw some large Duck
or Loon swimming
in the pond. Got home
to Cambridge at about
6 P.M. & brought my
Owls & Crow with me.
The water in Walden
was quite warm.
Monday, June 1, 1868.
  Clear and a lovely day.
Ther. about 70[degrees] - 75[degrees] - 
70[degrees]. Rose as usual and
exercised the dogs. Walked
down to school with
the boys. H. Henshaw
came up from school
with me & we took lunch
together. Then rode over
to Stoneham and took
the Humming Bird's
nest found Thursday.
It contained two fresh
eggs. Found a Humming
Bird's nest building and
shot a fine male Whip
Poor Will flying. Heard a Night
Hawk "boom" several times.
Got back at 7 P.M. The
linden trees are covered with
foliage as are also the maples,
willows, horse chestnut & apple
trees. The grass is about six
inches high & everything is
green.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Tuesday, June 2, 1868.
  Saw Red Start building in our linden tree.
Clear and a beautiful
day. Ther. about
60[degrees] - 66[degrees] - 60[degrees].
Rose at 5.30 A.M.
& studied with Theo.
Saw a Conn. Warbler in
our evergreens. After
I got home from school
stuffed the male Whip-
Poor-Will shot yesterday.
R. Deane got home from
Portland this A.M. with
a Mourning Warbler &c.
After dinner went up
to the swamp with Billy.
Found a Vir. Rail's with six
took them, Swamp Sp. with four
took them,  Vir. Rail 9 took them,
Vir. Rail 9 large young in eggs, took
one, Car. Rail 9 took them with
the nest. Billy pointed about
a dozen times at Rails &
also at a nest of young
Robins.
Wednesday, June 3, 1868.
  Clear and a most lovely
day. Ther. about 48[degrees] - 
60[degrees] - 50[degrees].
Rose at 5.30 A.M. and
shaved myself. Then
went up to the Russell's &
studied about an hour.
Went down to Henshaw's
after school and went out
on the marsh with him
to get a Least Sandpiper to stuff
but saw none. Shot a Sharp
Tailed Finch. Got home to
dinner at 3 P.M. Started at
5 P.M. for 'the swamp' with
Jup. Found a Vir. Rail's with
9 fresh, took 4, a Swamp Sp.
with two very handsome eggs,
took them; a Car. Rails with
7, took them; & a My. Yl. Thrts. just
finished. Saw a Wood Duck
& a Coot in the Swamp the
latter of which must  have
had eggs.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Thursday, June 4, 1868.
  Clear and a beautiful
day. Wind East.
Ther. about 45[degrees] - 65[degrees] - 
50[degrees].  Rose at 6 A.M.
& studied at the R's.
After I got back from
school stuffed the Sh.
Tailed Finch shot
yesterday. Then rode
up to Waltham with
E. Dodge & J. Croswell.
Searched first for the Towhee's
found about a week ago but
a Ed. & Jim were called to
remove the horse we could not
find it. Then got the Delafields
with three eggs, no birds around.
Had some difficulty in finding
the team again. Came down
through the Willows & found
a Virgiia Rail's containing
10 eggs. Shot a Short Billed
Marsh Wren.
Friday, June 5, 1868.
  Cloudy. Rained all
P.M. Ther. about 40[degrees] - 
50[degrees] - 45[degrees].
Rose as usual and
exercised the dogs.
Came home from
school & bought a pound
of White lead putty. After
dinner R. Deane came
down & we put the putty
& tar on our boat.
The apple tree blossoms
are now coming off.
Several canker worms
were seen on our trees today.
The grass in some places
has nearly got its growth.
The pear trees have shed
their blossomjs & the currants
& cherries are getting quite
large.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Saturday, June 6, 1868.
  A.M. cloudy. P.M.
clear but very warm. Ther.
about 60[degrees] - 80[degrees] - 70[degrees].
H. Henshaw woke me at 
4 A.M. by throwing pebbles
against my window. Got
Bill up & had the horse
harnessed. Rode over to
Stoneham. Cut off the limb
of our Hum. Bird's nest but
both the eggs rolled out & smashed.
Then got a Downy's with four.
Then drove a little further
on & shot a female Sc. Tan. Then
took lunch & a swim. Then across
to Lexington. Found a double
Yl. Bird's , a Br. Thrush's, two;
& a Prairie Warbler's just finished.
Came down through the Willows.
Found a Swamp Sp. four rotten
eggs & shot a male Sh Bill. Mar.
Wren flying. Got back at 5 P.M.
Stuffed Sc. Tan. & Mar. Wren.
A Black Poll Warbler was seen.
Sunday, June 7, 1868.
  Cloudy all day & rained
a number of times.
Ther. about 70[degrees] - 55[degrees] - 
52[degrees]. Rose as usual, shaved,
& exercised the dogs.
In A.M. attended church
as usual and found it
very hot & uncomfortable.
In P.M. R. Deane came
down and I went up
with him. Wrote a
letter to Dan in the
evening. Kanker worms
are getting thick.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Monday, June 8, 1868.
  A.M. cloudy. P.M.
clear and pleasant.
Ther. about 50[degrees] - 
70[degrees] - 60[degrees]. Rose at 6
A.M.  and studied
about thirty minutes at
the R's. Got late to school
in A.M. At 4 P.M.
started for the swamp
with Billy. Wore old
pants & shoes & took the
musket. Waded all the
P.M. up to the waist in
water. Shot a Blue Winged
Teal which was the only
thing that I got a shot at.
Billy was rather dull
& slow. Found several
Swamp Sparrow's. Got three
Swamp Sparrow's eggs &
a Maryland Yl. Throats
from a nest found the
other day. Took J. Nichols
to ride late in P.M.
Tuesday, June 9, 1868.
 A.m. clear & very
warm. P.M. cloudy
& had a thunder shower.
Ther. about 52[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 
60[degrees]. Rose at 6 A.M. &
studied about an hour
at the R's.
Walked down to school
with the boys & we all got
late. Had lunch as soon
as I got back from
school & then went in to
see Mr. Samuels carrying
in my so called Delafield's
which he decided was the
young of the Mary. and
Yl. Throat. Bought the Tax
Manual at Brewster's.
As soon as I got home
set to work on the Blue
Winged Teal shot yesterday.
Finished him at about 9.30
P.M.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Wednesday, June 10, 1868.
  Clear and quite cool,
in fact one of the pleasantest
days that we have had 
so far this spring.
Ther. about 60[degrees] - 65[degrees] - 
60[degrees]. Rose at 5.40 A.M.
and studied about an
hour at the R's.
When I got back from
school studied about two
hours at the R's. Had my
Teal for dinner & found it
excellent. After dinner took
Bill & with Ruth took my
boat up to the pond. First
harnessed in the General
but he ran away & broke
the gate so we took Tiger
next and went up all
right. The boat leaked so
that we could not go out
in it. Came home & went
on top of the Catholic Steeple.
Then went up to 'the pond'
& took a row in Theo's boat.
Thursday, June 11, 1868.
  Cloudy all day.
Began to rain at 12 N.
& rained hard all the
rest of the day.
Ther. about 60[degrees] - 60[degrees] - 
50[degrees]. Rose only in time
for breakfast & father
had to exercise my
dogs for me. Went
into  Boston from school.
Went first to father's
office. Then went to Parkin's
eating house & had some
boiled fowl & green peas.
Then went to Dr. Stearns',
& had a tooth refilled, the
old filling had been done by
Dr. Roffins. Then went
down to the bird store &
bought a bird trap. Got
home at 6 P.M. Studied
at the R's. in the evening.
The trees have all shed their
blossoms. The young Robins of
the first brood can now fly as well
as their parents.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Friday, June 12, 1868.
  Mr. Dexter called in to see my
birds in the evening.
Cloudy & rained most
of the time. Ther.
about 50[degrees] - 62[degrees] - 
55[degrees]. Rose as usual
& exercised the dogs.
Walked down to school
alone and got late.
After I got home had
lunch. Then Henshaw
came up & went with
me to the Prairie Warbler's
found last Saturday, but
found that it was only
a Yl. Warbler's; took one: Then
found a Br. Thrush's, one: took 
it. Then a Bl. Bill Cuckoo's
two broken. Br. Thrush's five:
took two. Shot a female Prin.
Creep. Warbler but spoilt her.
Came almost directly home
as it was raining fast
but found nevertheless a
P. Creep. Warbler's (probably) just
finished & another nest that
may prove a Yl. Bre. Chat's.
Saturday, June 13, 1868.
  Clear but rather warm.
Ther. about 60[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 
60[degrees]. Rose at 5 A.M.
and found Ruth
waiting for me.
Tookl Tiger and started
getting off at about 6
A.M. Put up the horse
at Chenery's. Found
a Red Eye's, three; an
Indigo Bird's, making,
& Maryland Yl. Thrt's ditto.
I shot two & R. two Weasels
with my horse pistol. I also
shot a male Yl. Warbler &
found the nest, a double one.
Then rode on through the
Willows, shot a Red Wing with
pistol, and took our lunch
at a brook in Lexington.
Then started for home & on
the way found a Prairie
Warbler's (probably), nearly
finished.

occurrenceRemarks:
Sunday, June 14, 1868.
  Clear & a beautiful
day. Had a heavy
thunder shower last
night. Ther. about
65[degrees] - 80[degrees] - 62[degrees].
Rose as usual.
Attended church in
A.M. In P.M. went
up & spent about
three hours with R.
Deane and afterwards
took a ride with
father into and
around Mt. Auburn.
Wrote most of evening.
Monday, June 15, 1868.
  Clear and a most
lovely day with a
strong West wind.
Ther. about 70[degrees] - 82[degrees] - 
68[degrees]. Rose at 6.15 A.M.
and studied about half
an hour at the R's.
When I got back from
school studied two hours
at R's. Then had
dinner. After dinner took
my musket & Billy & went
up to the swamp wearing
shoes instead of boots. Went
through the entire swamp
but did not get a shot at
anything. Went to a Maryland
Yl. Thrt's found last week
with two eggs, but it was empty.
Saw a King Bird's nest built
about two feet above the
surface of the water. Sat on
the piazza most of the
evening.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Tuesday, June 16, 1868.
  Clear and pleasant.
Ther. about 70[degrees] - 75[degrees] - 
65[degrees]. Rose a little
early & shaved. Walked 
down to school alone
& got late. Had lunch
as soon as I got home.
Then went up around
Mt. Auburn. Found
first an Olive Sided
Flycatcher's with three,
built in an apple tree,
but in trying to get the
nest down with a pole
tipped it over & broke
all the eggs. Then found
a nest in a spruce pine
exactly where I found
one last year; it contained
two eggs of which I took one.
Coming home, met father,
& took a ride with him
through Waverley. Burnt
tobacco in my cases in the
evening to drive out the bugs.
Wednesday, June 17, 1868.
  A.M. cloudy & rained
several times. P.M.
clear but cool.
Ther. about 70[degrees] - 80
[degrees] - 65[degrees]. Rose
at 6 A.M. and rode
up to the Ol. Sided Fly.
found yesterday. The
birds were both there, &
the male dashed around
my head, snappinjg his bill
fiercely, but the nest only
contained the one egg, left
yesterday. Took the 10.15
A.M. train for Andover
with father & mother.
In P.M. we all rode
over to North Andover.
Got home at about
8 P.M. & went up to the
R's. to study but Theo
was engaged. Brought
down the 'ponies' & studied
alone.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Thursday, June 18, 1868.
  A.M. cloudy. P.M.
clear. Rose at 6 A.M.
and studied about
thirty minutes with
Theo. Then took Tiger
& rode up to the
flycatcher's nest. She
was sitting on one egg
which I took after
shooting the bird.
Got back at 7.30 A.M.
In AM. stuffed the
Ol. Sided shot this morning
takling considerable pains
with her. Took the
2.30 express train for
Springfield, with mother.
We arrived there at 6 P.M.
the train stopping only
at three places. After
supper mother & I took a
walk of about two
miles.
Friday, June 19, 1868.
  Took the 7 P.M. train home & from the
cars saw a Black Duck start from her nest.
Clear and by far the
hottest day that we have
had yet. Ther. about
70[degrees] - 85[degrees] - 80[degrees].
Rose at about 7.30 A.M.
& found Ruth in the entry
of the Massasoit House
where we were stopping, he
& Mr. Dexter having arrived
there last night at 12.
They took breakfast with us &
then took the 8 A.M. train
for Northampton. After breakfast
I walked out of the city &
across the toll bridge and
then about three miles along
the straight road. Then turned
into the woods & searched for
eggs some time but found only two
Cat Bird's which out of disgust
I took. Then took a bath in a small
stream. Saw several Orchard Orioles
but although I had the horse pistol
in my bag, I did not dare
to fire at them as they were on the
[margin]skirts of the town.[/margin]

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Saturday, June 20, 1868.
  Clear and even warmer
than yesterday.
Ther. about 80[degrees] - 97[degrees] - 
85[degrees]. Rose as usual.
After breakfast rode
down to the Port & after
going to a Laundry after
Henshaw, found him
upon coming back to
his house. Then rode
over to Stoneham with
him but it was so hot
that we walked the horse most
of the way. First found a R. Eye,
with 4 advanced, & a Wood
Pewee's with two fresh.
Then drove down to the pond.
Found a Red Eye's just finished
& saw what must be a Solitary
Vireo building. Then rode on & got a
Night Hawk's which was laid
on the bare ground. Took lunch
in a shed where we got some
very cold water. Got back at 6 P.M.
Sunday, June 21, 1868.
  Cloudy and rained all day.
Ther. about 78[degrees] - 68[degrees] - 
60[degrees]. Rose as usual and
shaved. Then exercised
the dogs & got so warm
in disciplining Jup.
that I did not go
to church. Spent most
of the A.M. with my
birds & in cleaning &
arranging my eggs.
In P.M. B. Deane
called and stayed
several hours. The
canker worms have nearly
all disappeared.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Monday, June 22.
  Cloudy & misted most
of the day. Ther. about
52[degrees] - 60[degrees] - 54[degrees].
Rose at 5.30 A.M. &
studied with Theo.
When I got back
from school had lunch.
Then went up to 'the
pond' with R. Deane
and after baling out our
boat we rowed across
'the pond'. This was my
first row in the boat &
I like it very much.
Trolled for pickerel
& caught one of about
half a pound weight.
R. Deane knocked down
three Chimney Swallows
with a pole. Got in at
about 7 P.M. Studied
about two hours in
the evening.
Father began to mow to day.
Tuesday, June 23, 1868.
  A.M. cloudy. P.M.
clear. Ther. about
55[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 62[degrees].
Rose as usual and
exercised the dogs.
After I got back from
school had lunch as
usual and then went
up to 'the pond' with
Theo & E. Dodge. Went
across in Theo's boat &
went in swimming at
some ice houses on the other
side. Then left the boat &
dove into the middle of
the Pine Swamp. Found
two Green Heron's nests with
young. Came directly home &
then rode up there taking my light
gun. Shot the pair of one of the
nests & took one of three young.
Note of the male 'hough', of
females 'keou keou keou keou'.
Got back at 8 P.M. & read
most of the evening.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Wednesday, June 26, 1868.
  A.M. clear. Most of
P.M. do. Ther. about
60[degrees] - 65[degrees] - 56[degrees].
Rose at 5 A.M. &
studied at the R's.
Discovered that nearly
all my birds were
infected with grubs.
When I got back from
school took out all my
birds. In P.M. stuffed
the male Green Heron
shot yesterday. In latter
part of P.M. father & I
put a listing all around
my case & in the
evening father fumigated
it with sulphur. Studied
at R's. in the evening.
All the Swallows & most
of the Wrens have young.
The yard is almost filled
with young Robins.
Thursday, June 25, 1868.
  Clear & warm but with
a good breeze. Ther.
about 62[degrees] - 80[degrees] - 
70[degrees]. Rose as usual
& exercised the dogs.
Walked down to school
with the boys. When I got
back from school went
up to the R's & studied about
twenty minutes. Then
went to work on the
female Green Heron shot
Tuesday & got her eyes in
before dinner. After dinner
finished her. Went up to
'the pond' just at sunset,
and rowed for about an
hour. Got back at 9 P.M.
stopping some time at
the Deane's. Saw Hosts 
of fire flies for the first
time this year.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Friday, June 26, 1868.
  Clear & a most lovely
day. Ther. about 62[degrees] - 
78[degrees] - 70[degrees]. There are
only a very few canker
worms remaining. We got
in nearly all our hay
to day. Woke at 4 A.M.
intending to go fishing
with Theo but as my side
troubled me, I gave it up.
Rose as usual and
exercised the dogs.
Got dismissed at recess.
A Purple Martin came
into our yard & went to
several of my boxes but the
Swallows drove him off.
In P.M. went up to the
pond & fixed our boat.
While there Mr. Dexter
came up. Came home
at about 7 P.M.
Saturday, June 27, 1868.
  Clear but very warm.
Ther. about 70[degrees] - 88[degrees] - 
68[degrees]. Rose at 5 A.M.
& found Henshaw
waiting. Got off at about
5.30, taking the General
as Tiger was needed for
haying. First went to the
Ind. Bird's, & Mar. Yl. Thrt's which
R. Deane & I found two weeks ago
and got three eggs from the former
but found the latter gone.
Then got a King Bird's with 4.
Found a Sh. Bl. Mar. Wren building.
Searched the Willows meadow.
Then up into Lincoln: Saw a
Woodcock, & found an empty
Red Eyes. Then down into Lex.
& took dinner. Found a Chest. Side.
Warbler's with one deserted egg &
another one empty. Got a Pewee's
in a cellar with five fresh eggs.
Got back at 5 P.M. Then went
up & painted my boat & took
a swim.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Sunday, June 28, 1868.
  Clear & rather cool.
Ther. about 60[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 
60[degrees].  Rose as usual
& shaved. In A.M.
attended church. In
P.M. took Jup. up
to 'the pond' and also
finished the bows of our
boat to the water but
it still leaked a little.
Got back at about 5 P.M.
Then took a ride with father
& mother into Mt. Auburn
and up around Fresh Pond.
In evening wrote
to Charlie Carter. The
cherries are ripening
fast.
Monday, June 29, 1868.
  Clear & a beautiful day.
Ther. about 65[degrees] - 75[degrees] - 
68[degrees]. Rose at 5.30 A.M.
& studied at the R's.
Walked down to school
alone and got late.
We had short hours
to day as on Friday & got
dismised at the beginning
of the last hour. After
lunch Henshaw came up
and we rode over to Stoneham
taking the General. Got a
Red Eye's with 4 newly
fresh eggs. Then went up
to a nest which I found on
the 20th but it proved to be only
a Red Eye's. Fished for Pickerel
but caught none. Saw a pair
of Solitary Vireos. Male while
with his mate, uttered a noise like
the creaking of a sign board. Female
exactly like a Yl. Thrt.
Vireo. Got back at 6.30 P.M.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Tuesday, June 30, 1868.
  Clear and a beautiful
day. Ther. about 62[degrees] - 
75[degrees] - 65[degrees]. Rose at
5.30 A.M. and studied
at the R's. When I got
back from school had
some lunch. Then
went up to 'the pond'
with R. Deane taking
Billy. Made the
circuit of the pond and
landed once on the
other side. When we
came back across the
pond it was quite rough.
They were carrying away
the last remnants of the
Tudor boat house. Got back
at 5.45 P.M. & taking the
General in father's buggy we went
down & saw the boats go out at the
float. Then went up & took J.
Nichols out to ride.
Wednesday, July 1, 1868.
  Clear but rather warm.
Ther. about 65[degrees] - 80[degrees] - 
65[degrees]. Rose at 6 A.M.
and studied at the
Rs'. Walked down to
school with Jim & E. Dodge
& we all got late. Had
nearly 400 lines of Virgil
& two pages of Milo. Finished
our Greek review to day.
Read most of the time before
dinner. After dinner
made some red, blue &
green varnish, from
sealing wax. At 6 P.M.
went up to Dr. Mason's
with father letting Jup.
run behind. Dr. Mason
was not at home. Came
back over Wellington
hill. Tried to make Jup.
go into 'the pond' but he
would not. Went to bed
at 9 P.M.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Thursday, July 2, 1868.
  Clear & very hot. Ther.
about 74[degrees] - 88[degrees] - 75[degrees].
It was our exhibition
day but I did not go.
I was mentioned with the
rest of the class for all our
studies. Rose at 4 A.M.
& went up to the Rs'. Got
Joe Russell and went
up to 'the pond' fishing.
I rowed in my boat almost
around 'the pond', Joe
catching two rather small
pickerel. Then he took the oars
& I caught quite a large one.
Got back at 7.30 A.M. Examined
my birds & found them full of grubs
in spite of the sulphur. At about
10 A.M. went over to Stoneham
with E. Dodge taking Jup. First
got a Red Eye's nest, 4 eggs; Ed.
marked then in his box. Then went in
swimming. Then on to tavern: took lunch.
Rowed round the pond taking Jup.
Found a Red Eye's on a white pine.
Got back at 7 P.M.
Miss Bates called to see my birds in the evening.
Friday, July 3, 1868.
  Clear and the hottest
day that we have had.
Ther. about 80[degrees] - 94[degrees] - 
80[degrees]. Rose at 6 A.M.
& got two pages of Cicero
at the Rs'. First hour recited
over 400 lines of Virgil
which I had not looked
at. Then learnt four pages
of Cicero in the dressing room
with Theo. Got out at about
12 N. after having recited
our Cicero. After I got home
made some lemonade and
then went to sleep. Then
Farrar called and stayed
about an hour. After dinner
went up to 'the pond' with
Walter Deane and rowing
across in my boat we went in.
After I got back to Bruce's found
that I had  lost my key & went
back across the pond after it but
could not find it. Got back
at 9 P.M.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Saturday, July 4, 1868.
  Clear but the hottest
day that we have had.
Ther. about 80[degrees] - 100[degrees] - 
88[degrees]. Rose at 6 A.M. and
rode up to 'the pond' in
my wagon taking Billy.
Put a brass padlock
on my boat. After
breakfast R. Deane
called and went first
down to Mr. Dexter's rooms
where I got a ticket to the
steamer, Alert. Then we rode
down to the bridge. We had
to wait nearly an hour for
the boat to start. First single
then double scull race then
six and then four oared.
Then went to Ruth's grandfather's
& took dinner; then down
to the common & saw a
tight rope performance.
Got out at 5 P.M. At 7 P.M.
rowed across the pond with
Mr. Dexter & Ch. Deane & went
in swimming.
[margin]The Robins were flying over to the swamps[/margin]
Sunday, July 5, 1868.
  Clear but excessively
hot. We are now
having a bad drowt [drought].
Ther. about 80[degrees] - 97[degrees] - 
80[degrees]. Rose as usual.
After breakfast wrote
a letter to Dan.
Studied about an
hour before dinner.
After dinner studied
most of the afternoon.
Towards evening went
out a walked around
the garden. The currents
are reddening and
the strawberries are
beginning to decline.
All the swallows have
flown except one brood.
Heard a Robin singing
this evening

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Monday, July 6, 1868.
  Fumigated my birds in the evening.
Clear but very cool.
Ther. about
68[degrees] - 70[degrees] 60[degrees].
Rose at 6 A.M. &
went up to the Rs'
and studied about
half an hour on the
Greek. As soon as
we got to school Mr.
Bradbury gave us our
Greek papers containing
twenty questions, eight
of which however I
crossed off. Got out
at 12 N. being the
last one. Left only one
question unanswered.
After I got back from
school looked over my
birds. After dinner went
over to Newton with father
& saw Bob Smith's puppies.
Came down through
Brighton & saw Barnes.
Tuesday, July 7, 1868.
  Theo got my Virgil paper for me. Average 70 or thereabouts.
A.M. clear. P.M. cloudy
& rained about an hour.
Ther. about 60[degrees] - 80[degrees] - 
70[degrees]. Rose at 6 A.M.
& studied about an hour.
for the Virgil paper.
Got late to school. Went
to work on my paper
almost immediately but was
the last to get through.
After lunch at about 12
N. started shooting taking
my musket and Billy. First
down to 'the pond'. Put one of the
rowlocks into my boat. Shot
a female Red Wing & missed another.
Then into Snipe Swamp. Shot
a Red Wing, could not find him,
three Crow Blackbirds, found two,
& missed another Red Wing. Then into
forest on other side; fired five times
at Woodcock & knocked feather out.
Billy made some handsome points.
Fell in up to my neck. Heard several
Carolina Rails singing. Frank & Uncle
Henry came to day.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Wednesday, July 8, 1868.
  Cloudy all day. Misted in
the first part of A.M. 70[degrees] - 
80[degrees] - 65[degrees]. Rose as
usual & found Frank up.
After breakfast had Tiger
harnessed and rode first
up to Mr. Payson's with
Frank letting Jup. run
behind the wagon. Then
up through Waltham & down
by Cheneries where we tied the
horse & looked over the stock.
Coming down through lower
Belmont heard a Sht. Bill
sing & saw a large flock
of Bobolinks, the male clinking
but every now and then, one
or another of them would sing.
Got back at 12 N. & had lunch.
Then I went up to see R. Deane.
After dinner Frank & I went
up to the pond. I rowed around
the pond & he trailed with my spoon.
I went in at the wharf.
Read most of evening.
Thursday, July 9, 1868.
  Cloudy and misted
most of the day. Ther.
about 65[degrees] - 60[degrees] - 65[degrees].
Rose as usual. After
breakfast rode first over
to the rope walk with Frank
& saw them make ropes.
Then rode on to the
Reservoir and went about
half way around it.
Then over through Chestnut
Hills and down through
Newton & Watertown. Got
back at 12.30 P.M.
Loafed round till dinner
time. After dinner went
up to the pond with Frank
and rowed till 7. Made
a good paddle from an old
spoon oar and took it up with
me. Found Farrar & Croswell
in possession of my oars.
Read most of evening.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Friday, July 10, 1868.
  Clear and quite warm.
Ther. about 70[degrees] - 80[degrees] - 
70[degrees] - [degrees]. Rose
as usual. After
breakfast rode into
Boston in the cars
with Frank. then
went over to Charlestown
& around Bunker Hill
Monument. Had
no view as it was very
misty. Then went down
to the Navy yard and
went over the Ohio.
Saw Hiram the Profile House
chicken killer; saw the
Moniters. Then took a
lunch with father: then
bought a 25 lb bag of No 8, & then
5 lb bags of 4, 2, & 100. Ordered
a shooting coat. Frank took
the 3 P.M. train for home.
Went up to Lex in P.M. with
Henshaw and got the Marsh
Wren's nest  found two weeks
ago. It was finished but was empty.
Saturday, July 11, 1868.
  Clear but very warm.
Ther. about 75[degrees] - 85[degrees] - 75[degrees].
Awoke at 4 A.M. intending
to go shooting but fell
asleep again. Got up
at 7 A.M. & taking
breakfast immediately
started shooting taking
Billy. First down
the lane, shot a Red Wing.
Then around 'the pond'
to Tudor's, shot a Cedar Bird
& St. Sandp. both flying. Then
into Pine Swamp, fired
twice at Woodcock, third
shot killed him; old bird.
Then shot two more also
on the wing, one of which was
a young & the other an old bird.
Billy pointed the  last & retrieved
them all. Got back at 1 P.M.
Took a bath. In P.M. rode over
to see Mr. Barnes with Ruth but
he was not at home.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Sunday, July 12, 1868.
  Clear but exceedingly
hot in fact about the
warmest day that we
have had. Ther. about
80[degrees] - 100[degrees] - 95[degrees].
Rose quite late.
Did not attend church
as my face was swollen
up with a large boil.
Spent most of the day
reading Woods & Waters
one of Mr. Dexter's books.
In evening John
called and stayed
an hour or two with
us.
Monday, July 15, 1868.
  Clear but warm. 70[degrees] - 
80[degrees] - 75[degrees].
Rose as usual. After
breakfast rode into
Boston in the buggy
with Mother. Waited
several hours for her to
finish her 'shopping'.
Then she held the horse
while I got an ice cream
and bought at twenty
pairs of glass headed pins.
Got out of town at 1 P.M.
Then stuffed the young
Woodcock shot Saturday.
After dinner Henshaw called
with Mr. Stearn's who
looked over my birds.
After they had left went
up to 'the pond' with Jup.
and got him so he would
swim pretty well.
Got home at 8.30 P.M.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Tuesday, July 14, 1868.
  Clear but hot. Ther.
about 70[degrees] - 90[degrees] - 
75[degrees]. Rose as usual.
Spent the first
part of A.M. in
writing up my record
and diary. Then,
shook over my wings
which are infested
with grubs, and put
spirits turpentine on
them. Got a letter
from Dan saying that
he could go to Rye with
me. After dinner
rode up to Mr. Barne's
with father and saw
his puppies, two months
old, one of which he
offers to me. Spent about
an hour before supper in
teaching Jup. to carry.
Wednesday, July 15, 1868.
  Clear but excessively hot.
Ther. about 80[degrees] - 95[degrees] - 
82[degrees]. Rose at 4 A.M.
and went shooting taking
Billy. First up around
the Snipe swamp; found
several Long Billed Marsh Wrens
nest nearly done and saw
several birds for the first
time. Then cut down a Cock
in a narrow path through the
bushes. Then beat the Pine
Swamp but found no birds. Saw three
Least Sandp. Coming home
shot 4 Bobolinks at a shot. Got back
at 9 A.M. Then father went over
& got Mr. Sweet & family & they got
here at about 1 P.M. Spent
most of the P.M. in playing
croquet. They left at 6 P.M.
& I went up & spent several
hours with R. Deane who is still
confined by his toe. Had a short
thunder shower.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Thursday, July 16, 1868.
  Saw the first Least Sandp.
Clear and cool. Ther.
about 70[degrees] - 75[degrees] - 70[degrees].
Rose as usual. After
breakfast rode up to the
Brickyards where I tied
Tiger. Then leaving Billy to guard
the wagon, I went to the
Long Bill. Mr. Wren's nest.
Missed the mate at first shot &
brought him down from the
wing at second. Then took his
two nests & left. Then rode
up through Belmont making
Billy follow. When I got back
after leaving the nests, rode down
to the Square & got my box for
stuffing tools. then stuffed the
Marsh Wren. After dinner
went up to 'the pond' and
rowed for some time with
J. Croswell & J. Nichols. Went
in swimming. Saw seven
Wood Ducks. H. Henshaw came
up just at sunset & we rowed
half way across the pond.
Friday, July 17, 1868.
  Clear & cool with an
East wind. Ther. about
60[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 64[degrees]. Rose
at 5.30 A.M. Got Bill up
& he took me down to the Port
in the rockaway. Went
"Peeping" with Henshaw & got
fifteen Least Sandp. & one
Spotted. He got about the
same number. I shot a
number of mine flying singly,
some on the ground & five at
our rake. We found no Semi-
palmated. Shot the Spotted Sdp.
flying & fired at several others. Green
Heads very troublesome. Went in off
the point. Got back at 1 P.M.
After dinner went up to 'the pond'
& shot five Sp. Sandp. out of the boat,
three sitting & two flying, an adult
& young. Fired at a Kingfisher
flying. Got home at 8.30 P.M.
Ruth is abed with his toe.

Saturday, July 18. 1868.
  Clear but rather warm.
Ther. about 64[degrees] - 
80[degrees] - 70[degrees]. Rose as
usual. After breakfast
went up to the Rs'. At
10 A.M. started for 'the
pond' with the rest of the
boys for our picnic. Found
a man & boy out in my
boat. Went out to them in
the Rs' boat & made them
come in. They had broken the
chain to get it loose. Took Will.
Russell & J. Nichols across
in my boat. Then we went
in swimming & swam
nearly quarter of a mile. Had our
"grub" at about 12 N. Got
home at 3 P.M. After dinner
stuffed the two Cliff Swallows
shot yesterday, male & young.
At  7.30 P.M. rode up to 'the
pond' with J. Nichols & fastened
my boat driving a staple
into it.
Sunday, July 19, 1868.
  Clear and very warm.
Ther. about 75[degrees] - 81[degrees] - 
72[degrees]. Had a heavy
thunder shower late in
P.M. & it rained nearly
an hour. Rained lightly
nearly all the evening.
Rose as usual & shaved.
Attended church in A.M.
but found it exceedingly
warm. Went up to see
R. Deane in P.M.
Wrote a letter to Dan
in the evening.
The raspberries are ripe,
had the last box of strawberries
to day, currants on the
decline, gooseberries do.
cherries entirely gone &
blackberries yet green.
Wrens still singing
vigorously.

Monday, July 20, 1868.
  Cloudy & cold. Ther.
about  70[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 
60[degrees]. Rose at 4 A.M.
& went shooting taking
Jup.  First down to
'the pond'. Near the foot
of the lane Jup pointed
& two birds got up. I tried
both barrels but the caps
only mapped. Then missed
a shot; then knocked over
a Cock which Jup retrieved
perfectly. Saw three altogether.
Then back of brick ice house &
shot a Red Wing & young Musk 
Rat. Fired at a Vir. Rail. Then
into Pine Swamp & knocked
over another Cock. Then rode
around 'the pond'. Got back
at 9 A.M. Then rode up through
Lexington letting Billy follow.
Saw a male & several female & young
Orchard Orioles in Belmont.
After dinner cleaned two guns
& went up to the pond & took a row.
[margin]I saw three or four Woodcock & watched one for some time.[/margin]
Tuesday, July 21, 1868.
Cloudy & rather cold.
Ther. about 65[degrees] - 75[degrees] - 
70[degrees]. Rose at 3.40 A.M.
& taking Billy went up
to 'the pond'. Dropped a
couple of young Cock at the
foot of the lane & fired twice
at an old bird, probably
killing him at the last
shot. Billy pointed twice.
Coming home got five Bobolinks
at a shot. The males have not
yet changed. Got back at 6.30
A.M. After breakfast stuffed
a female Least Sandp. shot
Friday. Then rode down to
Henshaws but he was not
at home. Had four Cock for
dinnner. After dinner read
a while & then went up to
'the pond' with J. Nichols
& got a side ache rowing.
Saw Ciff Swallows.

Wednesday, July 22,1868.
  Clear but warm.
Ther. about 70[degrees] - 90[degrees] - 
75[degrees]. Rose as usual.
At 9 A.M. got Bill to
carry me down to
Henshaw's. We went out
on to the marshes where
we spent the forenoon.
I shot five & he four
Least Sandp. but no
Semipalmated. Saw two
Yellow Legs & two Ring
Necks. Went in swimming.
Bill came down for me
at 2.30 P.M. After dinner
went up to see R. Deane
& spent the afternoon
with him. In the evening
sat out on the piazza
as usual. Gooseberries
nearly all gone. Wrens still
singing.
Thursday, July 23, 1868.
  Clear but quite cool.
Ther. about 62[degrees] - 75[degrees] - 
70 - [degrees]. Rose as usual.
After breakfast went
up to the Rs' & got Theo
to go to ride. Rode up
through Lexington &
Waltham where we got
some sweet fern. Came
down through Waverly
where we saw a flock
of several hundred Crow
Blackbirds. In P.M.
went up 'to the pond'
and went in swimming.
I swam out to a stake
in 'the pond'. Then
rowed around 'the pond'
with J. Nichols. The
Crow Blackbirds & Red Wings
still continue to fly North
in large flocks, indeed it
seems as if there was no
end to them.

Friday, July 24, 1868.
  Cloudy & cold. Misted
several times during
the day. Ther. about 
64[degrees] - 75[degrees] - 60[degrees].
Intended to rise at
5 A.M. & go shooting
but my clock did not
wake me. Rose as
usual. Went up to
'the pond' in A.M.
& rowed for some
time. After dinner
went up to Dr. Mason's
with father & saw a
pointer bitch of his.
Got home at about
7 P.M. Then went up
to see R. Deane &
stayed about an
hour. The Harvards
raced with Yale at
Worcester. Harvard
17.28Â½: Yale 18.20
Saturday, July 25, 1868.
  A.M. cloudy. P.M. do.
Ther. about 65[degrees] - 80[degrees] - 
65[degrees]. Intend to start
at 4 A.M. but as it
was raining hard I did
not go. After breakfast
went up to 'the pond' with
Farrar. Went nearly around
in my boat. Fired at a
Chimney Swallow & Farrar
shot a Sp. Sandp. Then came
ashore & Farrar went home.
I went into the swamps 
with Jup. Fired at a Night
Heron. Shot a young male
Wood Duck which Jup. brought
out of the water. Started an
old Duck but did not fire
at her. Had fathers gun.
Got back at 4 P.M. Then
mounted the head of the
Wood Duck. In evening
cleaned the long double gun
& the musket.

Sunday, July 26, 1868.
  Clear but cool.
Ther. about 65[degrees] - 
75[degrees] - 70[degrees]. Rose
as usual & shaved.
Attended church
in A.M. In P.M.
took a ride with father,
mother, aunt, & cousins,
through Mt. Auburn
& around through
Belmont.
Monday, July 27, 1868.
  Clear but warm.
Ther. about 70[degrees] - 80[degrees] - 
70[degrees]. Rose about 4 A.M.
& went up to the Snipe
swamp taking Billy.
Came across a flock of about
ten Wood Duck & got both
barrels into them as they
rose, killing one. Then
got a shot at a single Duck
but missed him. Then
shot a Common Rail. Got
wet through on account of the
heavy dew. Got home at 7
A.M. After breakfast
got ready my things for packing.
Then went up to 'the pond'
with Will. Russell &
rowed for some time.
Coming home called in to
see R. Deane. In P.M.
went over to see Mr.
Barnes taking Jup.

Tuesday, July 28, 1868.
  Cloudy but did not rain.
Ther. about 70[degrees] - 85[degrees] - 70[degrees].
Rose as usual. After
breakfast went down
to the Square & got my
hair cut; also bought a
ball of shoe thread. After
I got home Theo brought his
buggy down & Bill & I rode
in with the baggage starting
at 10.30 A.M. Took the
12 N. train for Plymouth.
Read most of the way in
newspapers & "Verdant Green".
Had supper at 7 P.M.
After supper walked
down along the banks of
the river with Theo & watched
for the Chimney Swallows
but they did not go down in
any numbers. Heard a Whip-
poor-Will. On the road up
heard Field Sparrows, Towhees
& Red Eyed Vireos.
Wednesday, July 29, 1868.
  Alternately cloudy & clear
but altogether rather misty.
Ther. about 70[degrees] - 80[degrees] - 
60[degrees]. (Profile House) Rose at
6.30 A.M. & had breakfast
at the Pemegewasset House at
7. Took the 8 A.M. train
for Littleton where we
arrived at about 12 N. There
took a stage for the Profile
House. On the way heard
a Wood Wren & saw a small Flycatcher
that occasionally cried out "wit-
wit ta-wit ta". Theo & I
walked the three last miles,
getting in before the stage &
securing rooms No 31 & 32.
After dinner (at 4 P.M.) Theo
& I went down to the lake
& beat the water with flies in
vain for some hours. Saw a
Blackburnian Nest & heard
Hermit Thrushes & a Blk. Poll
Warbler. Got in to supper at
8 P.M. Went to be at 11 P.M.

Thursday, July 30, 1868.
Cloudy as usual here. Rained
hard for about an hour.
in A.M. Ther. about
60[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 60[degrees]. Rose
at 8 A.M. & had breakfast
very late. After breakfast  'loafed'
for about an hour in the
billiard room as it was raining
hard. Then saw Hiram &
after getting some beef for
bait went down to Echo
lake & trolled for Pickerel
but caught none. Saw   
a Muskrat, a Wood [?]
Winter Wren & numerous
Warblers. Got back to dinner
at 2 P.M. After dinner
went down to Profile lake
with Theo & I caught
ten & he two trout with bait
none of them being very
large. Got back at 8 P.M.
Saw a Yl. Crowned [?]
Friday, July 31, 1868.
  Cloudy but warm for this
region. Ther. about 65[degrees] - 78[degrees] - 
65[degrees]. Rose at 6 A.M.
& took at 6.30 breakfast.
Then rode down to the Basin
on Mardens coach & began
to fish down the stream.
After walking down about a
quarter mile we turned
up West branch where we
caught our best trout one of
mine weighing at Â¼ of a
pound. Took lunch at the
summit of Walker's Falls.
Then fished down to the
main stream which we
followed some distance below
the bridge. Saw no birds but
a few Hermits & a Canada
Flycatcher. Walked home
getting here at about 8 P.M.
with 130 trout, I seventy
& Theo sixty.

Saturday, August 1, 1868.
  Cloudy & rained most of
A.M. Ther. about
60[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 65[degrees].
Rose as usual & had
breakfast at 8 A.M. having
half the trout caught
yesterday. Mr. Prime
went down river & caught
about 100 small trout.
After breakfast walked
down past Echo lake with
Theo. Shot a young male
Canada Flycatcher. Saw
a male Black & Yl W. feeding
its young & shot a female Yl.
Th. Sparrow but could not
find her. Had some
lemonade at the old man's
at the foot of Bald Mt.
In P.M. stuffed the Can. Fly.
In the latter part of
P.M. went down to Profile
lake fishing but caught nothing.
Had a fine concert of Hermit
Thrushes just at evening.
Sunday, August 2, 1868.
  Saw a flock of about thirty Crossbills.
Clear and pleasant.
Ther. about 65[degrees] - 75[degrees] - 
70[degrees]. Rose as usual & had
breakfast at 8 A.M.
eating the remaining half
of the trout caught Friday.
After breakfast saw Hiram
kill chickens & wrote to
Dan & Ruth. Had divine
service at 11 A.M. in the
parlor but we did not however
attend. After dinner went
down to the trout house
& waited for Hiram to come
& feed them but he did not.
Then walked down to Bald
Mt. with Mr. Webster & Theo
& witnessed the sunset from
the summit. The country
was smoky so that we
had a very poor view.
Erected a pole on the summit.
Got back to supper at 8 P.M.

Monday, August 3, 1868.
  Clear & warm for this
region. Ther. about 65[degrees] - 
80[degrees] - 70[degrees]. Rose at
6 A.M. & took our breakfast
at 6.30. Went down on
Marden's coach to the
bridge. Fished down to
the Pool getting about
seventy trout. Then
fished down to the lower
bridge. Thence walked
up to the Flume with Theo
where we were photographed.
I subscribed to one paying
$1.00 in advance. Then
fished down the Flume
stream & caught  host
of small trout, right out of
one pool. Counted our
fish at the Flume house
& bought some maple sugar.
I rode up on young Marsden
& Theo on another Plymouth
stage.
Tuesday, August 4. 1868.
  Clear and a beautiful
day. Ther. about 60[degrees] - 
70[degrees] - 60[degrees]. Rose as usual.
In A.M. saw Hirams young
Sparrow Hawks and the
trout in the breeding house.
Then took my gun & went
down to Echo lake with Theo.
Here we rowed about for
several hours and fired the
gun to awaken the [?].
Then went in swimming.
Saw several large flocks
of Crossbills. After dinner
loafed about for an hour
or so and then played
a couple of games of
billiards. Spent most
of the evening on the piazza.
The house was very
full to night. Noran lake
to-morrow.

Wednesday, August 5, 1868.
  Cloudy. Rained most of
A.M. Ther about 60[degrees] - 
70[degrees] - 65[degrees]. Rose at 6 A.M.
Went down on the 7 A.M.
stage with Marden to the mouth
of West Branch. After bathing our
heads we started up the stream.
Walked with only a few stops,
steadily from 9 to 12 N.
A Cooper's Hawk followed us
for some little distance. Saw
also a Wood Wren & a Kingfisher.
Followed the stream up until
it became a small brook & finally
almost disappeared in moss.
Then gave up finding Noran
lake & eat lunch of ham sandwiches
& corn bread. Fished all the way
down & caught over a hundred
of which I took about sixty & Theo
forty. I caught three half pounders.
Got down to river at 6 P.M. Fanshaw
brought us up from the Basin in
his wagon. Got back at 8 P.M.
In evening skinned one of my trout.
Thursday, August 6, 1868.
  Cloudy and rained most
of the afternoon. Ther.
about 60[degrees] - 65[degrees] - 60[degrees].
Rose at 8 A.M. & had
breakfast as usual.
At 10 A.M. started with
Theo to ascend Mt. Cannon.
Took over two hours in
the ascent stopping
frequently to rest & talk.
Several large flocks of Crossbills
passed over us accompanied
by another bird unknown
to me but which may be
the White Winged species.
Spent about an hour on the summit
& had a splendid view
although the day was cloudy.
Came down in about thirty
minutes. After dinner
played two games of billiards.
Saw Doc. Wellington & C. Read
in the evening, also "Dummy".

Friday, August 7, 1868.
  Alternately cloudy &
clear. Ther about
65[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 65[degrees].
Rose at 6 A.M. &
had a hurried breakfast.
Theo & I got outside
seats. It Commenced
to rain when we got down
to the bridge and
continued for nearly
an hour. Got within
ten yards of a Broad Wing
Hawk, coming down the
valley. Reached Plymouth
at 12 N. Had dinner
at 12.20 & the cars
started at 1 P.M.
Got into Boston at 6 P.M.
and found Bill waiting.
Theo & I rode out with
him on the wagon.
Fed the Owls in the evening
& exercised the dogs which
were glad to see me,
particularly Jup.
Saturday, August 8, 1868.
  Cloudy & rained
most of the P.M. Ther.
about 62[degrees] - 75[degrees] - 65[degrees].
Rose as usual. After
breakfast went up to
see R. Deane but he
was in town. Then got
Theo Russell & went
up to 'the pond'. He
came home again and
I went out in my boat
& made the circuit of
'the pond'. Got a number
of full blown lilies
& came in getting home
at about 12 N. Found
Dan waiting for me.
After dinner we took
the 'shooting wagon'
& I took him up to
Climates Brook station
where he took the cars
for Concord. Read most
of the evening.

Sunday, August 9, 1868.
  Morning broke cloudy
& raining hard. Cleared
off about 10 A.M.
Rest of day clear.
and the afternoon the
lovliest I think that 
I ever beheld. The air
was clear as a crystal with
a cool breeze & the golden
sunlight played over
the freshly washed foliage.
R. Deane came down
in the first part of A.
M. & staid till noon.
After dinner wrote up
my record. Then took
a ride with father & aunt
Lizzie through Mt. Auburn
& around through Belmont
& Arlington. In the
latter town saw an albino
Robin that was almost
pure white.
Monday, August 10, 1868.
  Clear and warm.
Ther. about 65[degrees] - 78[degrees] - 
65[degrees]. Rose at 4.30 A.M
& went up to the Deane's
where I found R. Deane
& Mr. Dexter waiting for me.
Walked down to 'the pond'.
& found our boat nearly full
of water. Baled it out & carried
Mr. Dexter out to the point
when he backed out. Then
R. Deane shot a Kingfisher.
I fired next at one sitting.
Then shot a Red Wing (female) &
a Sp. Sandp. Got home at about
11 A.M. firing several times at
Md. Larks on the way. Shot 
five Robins at five shots in the
yard. Jup. retrieved them all
& I made him point dead. In latter
part of P.M. went up to the pond
& practiced casting with my
fly rod. Saw a flock of thirteen
(13) Wood Ducks. Saw two Sp. Sandp.
mount into the air.
Got home at 8 P.M.

Tuesday, August 11, 1868.
  Cloudy most of the
day. Ther. about
65[degrees] - 75[degrees] - 65[degrees].
Rose at 5 A.M. 
& taking Billy went
into the swamps. First
waded through the Snipe
swamp but saw nothing.
Then through the swamp
back of the Glacialis. Shot
three Night Herons (two
young & an adult changing)
& missed another. Saw two Green
Herons & shot a Car. Rail & a
Sp. Sandp, the latter flying.
Then back of Block island
& shot a young Hooded Merg,
four Least Bittern, & a Night
Heron all flying. Fired
three times to secure the
Merg. Saw both Long & Short
Billed Marsh Wrens.
Got back at 11 A.M. In
P.M. stuffed the Merg.
& Bittern. B. Deane called
in the evening.
Heard a Baltimore sing.
Wednesday, August 12, 1868.
  Clear and a beautiful
day. Ther. about
60[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 65[degrees].
Rose at 6 A.M. &
after breakfast took father
down to Somerville
depot. Then came back
& rode into Boston
with mother. Bought
several pairs of glass
eyes. five papers of pins
& two bundles of cotton
wool. Coming out called
to see H. Henshaw
& took him over through
Brighton and back again.
After dinner played
base ball for some time
with the R's & then played
billiards with E. Dodge.
Dan came down in
the last train. R. Deane
& E. Dodge called in the evening.

Thursday, August 13, 1868.
  Clear and a beautiful
day. Ther. about 60[degrees] - 
70[degrees] - 60[degrees]. Rose as
usual. After breakfast
took a ride through Lexington
with Dan & got some
several ferns. Had dinner
at 12 N. Started with the
baggage at 1.30 P.M. & took
the 3 P.M. train for No. Hampton
Dan & I rode down in the
smoking car. Arrived here
at 6 P.M. After supper
we took a walk over to
the cell pond & saw several
Green Herons & a Bittern.
Just at dusk saw immense
flocks of Swallows flying
Southward. Spent most
of the evening at the
Ocean Haven & saw Will
Philbrick & Frank. Went
to bed at 9.30 P.M. Heard
an Indigo Bird sing.
Friday, August 14, 1868.
  Clear & cool with
a good breeze. Ther.
about 60[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 65[degrees].
Intended to rise at 4 A.M.
but did not wake till 5.30.
Loafed most of A.M.
as my old enemy the
side ache has again
attacked me. In P.M.
went down to the beach
several times. Saw several
Green Herons & a large
flock of Ring Necks.
In the evening went
over to the Ocean House.
Went to bed at 9.30
P.M.

Saturday, August 15, 1868.
  Clear and a pleasant
day. Ther. about  60[degrees] - 
75[degrees] - 65[degrees]. Rose at 
4 A.M. & went over to
the Eel pond with Dan,
getting there just as it was
getting light. Soon 4 Rd. Breast
Snipe came along & I shot
three & Dan one on the wing. I
shot three more Snipe &
a Yl. Legs & D. another
Snipe & Yl. Leg. Sat in Als
Nash's gunning house. Three
Black Ducks came over
his decoys & I fired at them
but missed. Saw several Grass
Birds. Got back at 8.30 A.M.
& after breakfast picked the
birds with Tom P. Then rode
over to the Farragut House
to see Dave Philbrick but he was
out. Came round by Rye Harbor.
Counted the Swallows that pass
along the beach in 30 minutes
result 1000 or 32000 a day.
Sunday, August 16, 1868.
  First part of A.M.
rainy. Cleared up at
about 10 A.M. Rest of
day clear & pleasant.
Ther. about 60[degrees] - 68[degrees] - 
60[degrees]. Rose as usual.
After breakfast shaved.
Saw several large flocks
of Yl. Legs & one Tell
Tale flying over toward
the Eel pond. Then
watched a Loon for some
time through my glass.
After dinner walked
over to the Farragut
house with Dan & saw
three Loons. Got back
at 6.30 P.M.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Monday, August 17, 1868.
  Clear and pleasant. Ther.
about 60[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 65[degrees].
Rose at 4 A.M. with
Dan & went over to
the pond. The morning
was exceedingly cold &
we waited there for over
an hour before we saw
any birds. Saw then Black
Ducks. Shot two Purple
Martins. Then four
Yellow Legs came along., I got
three & Dan got a stray
one. Shot also Solitary & on
the way home, a Common Rail.
After breakfast went back
to the pond and I shot a
Yl. L. & a Sol. & Dan, a Yl. L.
Got our boat & rowed up, I shooting
a Kingfisher on the wing,
& a Wilson's Snipe flying. In
P.M. stuffed a Semi. Sdp. (female)
& a P. Martin (male) & D. a Yl. 
L. Our tame duck came
in the evening. Bathed in A.M.
Tuesday, August 18, 1868.
  Clear and a pleasant day.
Ther. about 60[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 60[degrees].
Rose at 4 A.M. and
went over to the Eel
pond. The morning was
very foggy so that no
birds were flying.
Went over to the beach
with Dan & the saloon
keeper & shot over twenty
[?] principally Semi-
palmated. Got back at
8.30 A.M. After breakfast
Dan cleaned his gun
& we plucked our birds.
Then took a bath.
Water rather cold but the
surf magnificent.
After dinner went over
to the pond & made
a shooting booth. Saw
a Tell Tale. Saw  a Sandling
this morning.
R. Deane came today.

  Clear and warm but
very windy. Ther. about
70[degrees] - 75[degrees] - 70[degrees]. Rose
at 4 A.M. and with
Dan & Ruth went shooting.
Put out our decoys on
the point. Soon a flock
of about fifteen Turnstones
came along & hovering over
our decoy. We each got a male.
Dan shot a Snipe (Red Breast)
as it was hovering over the decoy.
Shot also a number of Peeps
In A.M. we stuffed each our

Took a bath. Surf fearful &
water rather cold. After
dinner went along the
beach with Ruth. He shot two
Piping Plover at a shot & fired at
some Turnstones. Saw numbers
of Bonaparte's Gulls. Came back
& went over to Eel pond. Mr.
Nash warned us to leave.
Went to bed at 9.30 P.M.
Thursday, August 20, 1868.
  Cloudy & rained most
of P.M. Ther. about
60[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 70[degrees].
Rose at 4.30 A.M.
& went over to the pond.
Mr. Dexter took father's
gun & went with us.
I shot three Yl. Legs (two
flying). Dan shot several
Yl. Legs and then Tringa maculata
Sandp. Came back along
the beach & saw a [?]
H Plover & a Bonaparte's Gull.
Bathed as usual. Water
very cold. After dinner
went over to the Eel pond
with Mr. D. & got a  Yl. Legs
on the other side. He shot a
Yl. Legs & another unknown
Sandpiper Hic. himantopus both wing broken.
Saw a Long Billed Curlew.

Friday, August 21, 1868.
  Clear and rather warm.
Ther. about 60[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 
65[degrees]. Rose at 5 A.M.
and went over to the
Eel pond. Shot two
Yl. Legs sitting as
soon as we got there.
Then shot a Kingfisher
flying. Came back along
the beach but saw
nothing. After breakfast
had our photographs
taken with dog, guns
&c.  Then bathed. Water
quite cold but very good.
Then stuffed the Stilt
Sandp. shot by Mr. Dexter
yesterday. After dinner
went over to the harbour
with Dan & W. Phil
& shot a Yl. Legs flying
& 24 Peeps. Mr. Dexter
took Ruth to Exeter in P.
M.
Saturday, August 22, 1868.
  Clear and pleasant.
Ther. about 60[degrees] - 75[degrees] - 
65[degrees]. Rose at 7 A.M.
After breakfast read
for a while. Mr. Dexter
left by the 8.30 train.
Then went over to Rye
Harbour. Got a boat & fished
for nearly two hours.
Caught a number of perch,
post fish, & two large
Pollock. Saw two turnstones
& two Black Breasted Plover.
Got back at 2.30 P.M.
Sat on the piazza most
of the P.M. and got our
photographs. After supper
walked over to the Farragut
House and got a soda
at the refreshment saloon.
Came back along the beach.
Then went over to the
Ocean. Home & spent
the rest of the evening.

Sunday, August 23, 1868.
  Clear and a beautiful
day. Ther. about 60[degrees] - 
70[degrees] - 65[degrees]. Rose at
8 A.M.. After breakfast
shaved. Bathed at
eleven. Water delightfully
warm for the ocean
but the surf rather
poor. Took dinner
together at the Ocean
House. After dinner
we all rode over to
Hampton beach in
an open beach wagon.
Saw a Coot. Got back
at about 8 P.M. After
supper wrote a letter
to C. Carter. Went to
bed at 10 P.M.
Monday, August 24, 1868.
  Clear & pleasant.
Ther about 60[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 
60[degrees]. A.M. calm but
in the afternoon a
strong Southerly breeze
arose. Rose at 5 A.M.
& went over to the harbour
with Dan & Ruth. Fired
at a G. Blue Heron. Got
back at 7.30 A.M. Dan
packed up after breakfast
and left by the 10.30 coach.
Then Ruth & I took a
boat & fished awhile catching
two or three cunners. Ran
her into the surf. Then
took a bathe. Water quite
warm. After dinner went
over to the Eel pond alone
& made a shooting hut
& killed two Yl. Legs at
a shot sitting. Went to bed 
at 9 P.M.

Tuesday, August 25, 1868.
  Clear and pleasant.
Ther. about 60[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 
65[degrees]. Rose at 4.30 A.M.
& went over to the pond
with R. Deane. I rowed
up to the head in my
boat and soon after I
landed I got 4 Yl. Legs.
Shot three more Yl. Legs
in the course of the morning
& one Rd. Br. Snipe.
I saw two Tell Tales.
Got back at 8 A.M.
After breakfast picked the
birds. R. Deane shot
eleven Peeps at a shot.
Then went out after [?]
but saw none. Got the
boat in the breakers &
swamped her purposely.
In the P.M. stuffed
the Sandp. & R. Deane a
Semi. Sandp. They had
a grand ball at the
Ocean House this evening.
Wednesday, August 26, 1868.
  Clear and pleasant.
Ther. about 60[degrees] - 75[degrees] - 
60[degrees]. Rose at 5 A.M.
and went over to the
Eel pond. Got a shot at
two Tell Tales but the caps
only mapped. Shot a
Kingfisher flying. Then
R. Deane shot a Teal &
fired at the other as it rose.
It lit on the sea so I dragged
my boat across & went out
after it but could not get
a shot. Then shot two Tell 
Tales one sitting & the other
flying. Bathed as usual.
After dinner R. Deane
stuffed his Teal & I went
over to the pond. Shot
a Kingfisher & a Yl. Legs.
Fired at a Golden Plover.
W. Philbrick killed a very
handsome Golden Plover.

Thursday, August 27, 1868.
  Clear and pleasant.
Ther. about 60[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 
65[degrees]. Rose at 5 A.M.
and went over to the
pond with R. Deane.
Did not get a shot
at anything. W. Phil.
shot a Tell Tale and
a Marbled Godwit.
Came back along the
beach and shot a
female Sandling.
After breakfast stuffed
the Sandling. Then
bathed. Water quite
warm. Father left to
day. In P.M. went up
to the mill pond but
saw no ducks. Then
down to the Eel pond
& with R. Deane shot
three Knots flying.
Wrote a letter to father
in the evening.
Friday, August 28, 1868.
  Clear but cool.
Ther. about 60[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 
60[degrees]. Intended to rise
this morning as usual
but we did not wake
till 7 A.M. After breakfast
we each stuffed one
of the two Knots shot yesterday.
Then bathed with Bailey.
Water very warm.
After dinner went along
the beach. Shot three
Ring Necks but spoilt
them all. R. Deane
shot a Piping & a Ring
Neck Plover. Waited
some time at the pond
but saw nothing.
Got back to supper.
Ruth packed up this
evening.

Saturday, August 29, 1868.
  Clear with a very strong
South wind. Ther. about
60[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 65[degrees]. Rose
at 5 A.M. & found
Harry Bailey waiting
for me. Went over
to the pond with him.
Brought down a Marsh
Hawk but of course he
got away while I was
loading. Saw a Golden
Plover. On the way
home searched the little
pond & killed two Eng. Snipe,
and a Tell Tale; all flying.
After breakfast stuffed
the Tell Tale. Ruth left
by the 8 A.M. coach.
Bathed at 11 A.M. with
Bailey. Water remarkably
warm. In P.M. went over
to the pond with Bai. & shot
five Yl. Legs & 2 Grass Birds.
Fired at a Tern. After supper
stuffed one of the grass birds (female).
In evening had a letter from
both father & mother.
Sunday, August 30, 1868.
  Clear and pleasant.
Ther. about 70[degrees] - 80[degrees] - 
70[degrees]. By far the warmest
day that we have had
since I have been here.
Did not rise till 9 A.M.
After breakfast went in
with Frank Ph. & H. Bailey.
We stayed in nearly forty
five minutes as the water
was quite warm. When
I got home shaved myself.
A large mackeral fleet
passed by. After dinner
wrote to both father &
mother. Then went
down to the beach and
stayed till supper time.
Late in the evening
heard numbers of Upland
Plover & Bobolink flying
over.

Monday, August 31, 1868.
  Clear and very warm.
Ther. about 70[degrees] - 78[degrees] - 
70[degrees].  W. Phil woke me
at 4 A.M. & we went
over to the pond.
A flock of Teal came
down to my decoys
and I crept up to them
on hands and knees. Fired
one barrell into them sitting
shooting a couple with No. 2
& the other flying bringing
a third with No. 8. W.P. shot
another Teal & a Killdeer
Plover. Got back at 8 A.M.
After breakfast skinned one
of the Teal (a male).
Bathed as usual.
After dinner went over
to the pond. Shot a Purple
Sandp. [margin]Certainly an error of identification or a slip of the pen, I cannot remember which.[/margin] On the beach, saw
a Turnstone. Came back
early and stuffed the Sandp. (male).
In the evening showed Joe my birds.
Tuesday, September 1, 1868.
  Weather very changeable.
Morning broke very cloudy
& foggy. Had a thunder
shower in A.M. P.M. cloudy.
Ther. about 70[degrees] - 75[degrees] - 70[degrees].
Waked at 5 A.M. but as
it was misty I did not
go shooting. I am troubled very
badly with a weak stomach.
After breakfast walked
along the beach for an
hour or more with Bailey.
Then read till dinner time.
After dinner went over
to the pond. Shot a Yl.
Leg. Fired at a Wil. Tern
& a Sol. Sandp. Shot the
Yl. Leg with a cartridge.
W. Phil. shot a Black Tern.
Mr. P. shot a Teal & a
Common Tern.

Wednesday, September 2, 1868.
   Clear and cool. Ther.
about 60[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 65[degrees].
Tom waked me at 4 A.M.
& taking my tame duck
I went over to the pond
with him & Willie. There
was a slight fog & the
air was very sharp. Tom,
went to Nash's hut & shot
into three Teal, killing them
all. Then I fired at a Musk
Rat taking him for a Teal & killed
him. Went up the pond in my
boat & just before I got to my
decoys Abbion fired into them.
Sat there the whole morning
but saw nothing but Grass Birds
& Solitaries. Shot a Yl. Legs. Soon
after breakfast father came & I packed
my birds. Rode over to Dave P's with
Tom & paid for my boat. The
surf was tremendous. Took the
5.30 P.M. train & arrived at
Amesbury at about 8 P.M.
Saw a Night Hawk.
Thursday, September 3, 1868.
  A.M. clear. P.M. cloudy
with East wind. Ther.
about 60[degrees] - 68[degrees] - 60[degrees].
Rose at about 8 A.M. &
shaved. Spent the A.M.
in uncle Albert's shop.
Had Tom's two Teal for
dinner. After dinner
took a ride to Amesbury
Port with father, mother
& Aunt Abbie & rode into
Hawkswood. Saw a Wood
Pewee. Got back at 7.30 P.M.
After supper took a walk
with father. Was troubled
very much with the heart
burn during the evening
but my sore stomach is
much better.
