Friday, September 4, 1868.
  Cloudy and had
several heavy showers
in P.M. Ther. about
60[degrees] - 68[degrees] - 62[degrees].
Rose as usual.
After breakfast took
the coach for Haverhill
with father. Got home
at about 12N. Found
most of the peaches
ripe. After dinner
unpacked my birds.
Then took fathers gun
and went up to the
pond. Saw two Wood
Ducks go into the swamp.
Fired at a Bl. Wng. Teal
at the foot of the lane &
shot a Rail. Then went
into the swamp & shot
a Bittern & a N. Heron
both flying. Had to get an
Irishman to bring me a 
plank before I could get
out of the swamp.
Heard Swamp Sparrow & M. Vl. Thrts singing.
Monday, September 5, 1868.
  Morning broke rainy & 
stormy. Rained till 10 A.M.
when it cleared up. Rest
of day clear and beautiful.
Ther. about 60[degrees] - 75[degrees] - 
60[degrees]. Woke at 4 A.M. but
as it was raining hard
I did not start shooting.
After breakfast took Billy
& explored the swamps
thoroughly as far as Smith's
pond. Shot four Rails (lost
one) & a Night Heron
all flying. Wounded a
Bittern badly but lost
him. Fired twice at
Snipe and saw three.
Got back at 4.30 P.M.
After dinner took a ride
with father. In the
evening went up to R.
Deane's & saw his Gallinule.
Saw several Bank & Barn
Swalllows.

Sunday, September 6, 1868.
  Clear and a lovely day.
Ther. abouit 56[degrees] - 
70[degrees] - 60[degrees]. Rose a
little early and plucked
a Bittern and Night
Heron. Attended church
in A.M. In P.M.
took a ride with father
around Spot Pond in 
Stoneham. Had my
Heron for dinner &
found them excellent.
Heard a Yl. Throat Vireo
singing this afternoon.
Wrote a letter to Dan
in the evening.
Monday, September 7, 1868.
  Cloudy and had a
heavy shower every two
or three hours. Ther.
about 60[degrees] - 75[degrees] - 65[degrees].
Rose at 4 A.M. & went
shooting. Fired twice at
Wood Ducks at the foot
of the lane. Then went
through the swamp
and up to Smith's pond.
There shot two N. Herons
sitting off the same branch.
Came down to Block island.
Shot a N. Heron flying, two
Snipe flying & a Bittern
flying besides four Car. Rails
also on the wing. Billy
pointed a number of times.
The Rails all flew like Snipe
rapidly doubling & twisting.
Got soaked to the skin.
Got back at 11 A.M. Then plucked
my birds. After dinner
cleaned my double barrell
& took a ride with J. Nichols.

Tuiesday, September 8, 1868.
  Clear and rather cold.
Ther. about 54[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 
60[degrees]. Rose at 4 A.M.
and took Billy & Jup.
Shot four Rails, three 
Teal, two Night Herons
& two Green Herons.
Shot two of the Teal
flying and the third
on the water. They were
all I saw. Saw a number
of Wood Ducks.
Got back at 11 A.M.
Had three Night Herons
& a Bittern for dinner.
After dinner intended
to have had a pigeon shoot
but Ruth, did not wait for
me. Went up to the swamp
& shot two Night Herons
flying. Fired at some
Wood Ducks flying. Saw
Chimney & Barn Swallows.
Heard Virginia Rails &
L. Bill. Marsh Wrens.
Wednesday, September 9, 1868.
  First part of A.M. clear.
Had a shower about
noon. P.M. cloudy.
Ther. about 58[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 
60[degrees]. Rose at 4 A.M.
& went into the swamp.
Saw nothing but two Teal
& a few Snipe. Coming out
of the Swamp saw two
Yellow Legs, a Tell Tale &
a Virginia Rail. Got back
at 9 A.M. Saw about fifty
Wild Pigeons flying over.
Bailey came out to see me
at about 10 A.M. & Henshaw
also called. Took a ride
with Bailey through
Lexington & Waltham.
After dinner went up to
the pond with R. Deane
& had a pigeon shoot
& killed several pigeons. Saw
about twenty Wood Ducks.

Thursday, September 10, 1868.
  Cloudy all day.
Rained all of P.M.
Ther. about 60[degrees] - 75[degrees] - 
62[degrees]. Rose at 4 A.M.
but as it was raining
hard I went back to
bed again. After breakfast
picked a basket of plums
and read for several
hours. Then began
on one of the Blue Winged
Teal shot Tuesday.
Henshaw called while
I was stuffing him.
Got through by dinner
time. After dinner read
a while. Then took Billy
and went up to the
swamp. Came upon four
Blue Wings & shot two. Then followed
the others & killed them both but
on coming back found my first
two gone. Coming out just at
dark shot a Wood Duck
flying knocking him all up.
Friday, September 11, 1868.
  Cloudy and rained
several times. Ther.
about 66[degrees] - 85[degrees] - 
80[degrees]. Rose at 5 A.M.
and went shooting.
Went first into the swamp
where I saw about a dozen
Wood Ducks go down.
Searched for them nearly
two hours and at last Billy
got them up but they did not'
come within shot. Then
went over to the pond and
rowed around it  in my new boat.
Fired twice at a Fish Hawk.
Met the Russells & went
up to Spy Pond with them.
Shot a Woodcock in the pine
swamp to Billie's point.
Saw a Wilson's Tern on Spy
Pond. Shot also Virginia Rail
& a Gl. Wng. Woodpecker.
Got back about 2 P.M. After dinner
went up to the railroad
& shot two Night Herons flying.
Fired also at a Wood Duck flying.

Saturday, September 12, 1868.
  Cloudy but did not
rain. Ther. about 70[degrees] - 
80[degrees] - 70[degrees]. Rose at
5 A.M. and went up
to the swamp taking
my shortest double barrell.
Shot a Green Winged
Teal sitting at a very
long shot. Saw several
Wood Ducks & fired at one
flying. Then went over
to the pond and took
my boat. Got a good shot
at an Osprey and wounded
him badly. Then chained
my boat and went first
to Pint Pond where I saw
four Wood Duck. Then
to Block Island where 
I shot a Snipe. Got back
at 11. Then stuffed the Teal.
After dinner went up to the swamp.
Saw the first Autumnals & Rusties.
Watched a Rail & Musk Rat.
Shot a Wood Duck flying
but could not find him.
R. Deane saw some Tit Larks.
Sunday, September 13, 1868.
  Alternately cloudy
& clear. Ther. about
65[degrees] - 78[degrees] - 70[degrees].
Rose as usual and
shaved. Attended
church in A.M.
In P.M. went up
to the Deane's and
saw Ruth's Wood Duck
and Lucie's presents.
Wrote most of the
evening. Heard a
Warbling Vireo singing
to day. Had a heavy 
shower in P.M. The
peaches are getting
past their prime.

Monday, September 14, 1868.
  Clear and a very
pleasant day. Ther.
about 60[degrees] - 65[degrees] - 
60[degrees]. Rose at 4 A.M.
and went into the
swamp. Found Ruth
there who had shot
a Night Heron and
fired several times at
Wood Ducks. I soon
got a flying shot at a female
Wood Duck & brought her
down. Then shot another
but could not find her.
Then over to Block Island
and shot a Snipe & a Rail;
Got back at 1 P.M. The
Russells each shot a Pd. Bill.
Grebe & Joe an old Wil. Tern.
After a dinner at 2, went
up to the pond & shot two
Fish Hawks, one flying. Fired
at a Grebe & finished a Teal
for Hittinger.
Tuesday, September 15, 1868.
  Clear and cool. Ther.
about 55[degrees] - 65[degrees] - 60[degrees]. 
Had a slight frost last
night. Went down to the
the High School to day but
after hearing our lessons
given out we were dismissed.
Theo. & I got our lessons
soon after getting home.
Then went up to the
pond and pulled around
in my boat but saw
nothing. Went over to the Glacialis
where I shot a Tell Tale &
wounded a Yellow Leg badly.
Then watched a couple of
Pd. Bill. Grebes for some time &
at last got them both at a shot.
Got back to dinner. After
dinner went up to the railroad
with H. Henshaw & shot 8 Robins
in their roosting place & a
Night Heron flying. Heard
many Autumnal Warblers
migrating after dark.

Wednesday, September 16, 1868.
  Clear and pleasant
but very windy in
P.M. Ther. about
60[degrees] - 65[degrees] - 58[degrees].
Rose as usual.
After school studied
with Theo. After
dinner H. Henshaw
came up and I stuffed
the adult female Grebe
shot yesterday. After
supper stuffed the
young bird also a female.
The Bobolinks have
all left us.
Grapes reddening.
Bartlett pears just
beginning to get ripe.
Thursday, September 17, 1868.
  Clear and pleasant
but cold. Ther. about
42[degrees] - 58[degrees] - 44[degrees].
The coldest day that
we have had. Rose
a little early and
shaved. After getting
home from school cut the
wings off my Fish Hawk.
After dinner went up
to the railroad with
Henshaw. Saw a number
of Wood Ducks and
flock of Teal. Then
went into the wood &
I shot four & Henshaw
seven Robins. Saw numbers
of Savannah Sparrows &
Swamp Sparrows. Fired at
a Night Heron & saw
several Car. Rails. Heard
Autumnal Warbler flying
as late as 10 P.M.

Friday, September 18, 1868.
  Clear but cool. Ther.
about 38[degrees] - 60[degrees] - 
50[degrees]. Rose as usual. Saw
before breakfast an albino
Robin on our cherry
tree. After school had
our annual football
match in which the 3rd
beat the 4th & the 1st
& 3rd beat 2nd & 4th.
Got back to dinner. After
dinner started for the taking
my long gun & live duck.
I had scarcely got my
bird out when I got a shot
at a Wood Duck but missed him.
Then fired into a flock & knocked
one but failed to find him. Then
fired both barrells into six Bl.
Wing Teal killing four. Then
shot a single Blue Wing & a few
minutes after one of two Green
Wings, both flying over my
decoy. Got back to supper.
Saturday, September 19, 1868.
  A.M. clear. P.M. cloudy.
Ther. about 42[degrees] - 65[degrees] - 
52[degrees]. Rose at 4 A.M.
and taking Billy went
up to the swamp. Saw
a Turtle Dove & a Com. Coot
before it was fairly light.
As it was fast getting light
the Snipe began to fly over
the swamp in large numbers.
Got a flying shot at a Teal but
missed him. Then heard Swamp
Sparrows, Ma. Yl. Thrts, & C. Rails
singing. Went up to Port pond
& shot two handsome male Wood
Ducks with one barrel & a female
with the other. They were accompanied
by several Teal. Got back at 10 A.M.
Then stuffed a male Wood Duck.
After dinner went up to the
swamp & shot a Bl. W. Teal
& a Snipe but failed to get the
latter. Saw a Night Hawk.
Studied at R's in the evening.
Heard a Wren sing.
Saw several Snow Birds plainly.

Sunday, September 20, 1868.
  Cloudy & rained most
of the day. Ther. about
56[degrees] - 65[degrees] - 60[degrees].
Rose as usual and
shaved. Attended
church in A.M.
Wrote a letter to C. Carter
in the evening, and
to Dan in the afternoon.
The woods and gardens
are literally alive with
Autumnal Warblers and
there seems to be a
continual stream passing
over during the whole
night as it is impossible
to be out in the open air
ten minutes without hearing
them. Most of the peaches
except the latest varieties
have gone. The grass is
very green and only the
maples in the swamps have
turned as yet.
Monday, September 21, 1868.
  Clear and a most lovely
day. Ther. about
50[degrees] - 56[degrees] - 50[degrees].
Rose as usual. Walked
down to school with E.
Dodge & Theo. Studied
at the R's immediately
after getting back.
After dinner went up
to the swamp with
Henshaw and met
R. Deane there. Then
went over to the railroad
and shot three Robins.
H. shot four. Fired
once at a Night Heron.
Got back at 7.30 P.M.
After supper cleaned
both of my double guns.
Saw numbers of Snipes
& a Solitary Sandpiper,
but no ducks. Theo carried
a petition around this evening
for having Saturdays
again.

  A.M. clear. P.M.
cloudy. Ther. about
40[degrees] - 50[degrees] - 50[degrees].
Rose as usual and
walked down with
the boys. Had a fire
in the furnace to day for
the first time. After
school studied with
Theo. Then went up
to 'the pond' and
to Pout Pond
but saw nothing. Carried
up two Teal decoys.
Heard numbers of Cat
Birds & saw a Night
Hawk. Got back at 7 P.M.
After supper carried
around a petition with
J. Russell for getting
our Saturdays back
again.
Wesnesday, September 23, 1868.
  Cloudy and rained
most of the day.
Ther. about 50[degrees] - 60[degrees] - 
60[degrees]. Rose at 3.30 A.M.
and went up to the
pond where I found
R. Deane waiting for
me. Got out our decoys
long before light. Just
as day was dawning
three Teal lit and I got
one of them as they
sprang. Started back at
6 A.M. and got my dry
clothes on in time for breakfast.
Saw a Tit Lark. After school
studied as usual.
After dinner went up to
the swamp but saw
nothing but a few Snipe,
Sora & Virginia Rails
& did not fire a shot. Saw
several Autumnal Warblers.

Thursday, September 24, 1868.
  Cloudy and sprinkled
a little in P.M.
Ther. about 60[degrees] - 65[degrees] - 
50[degrees]. Rose as usual &
walked down with the
boys. After getting
home from school had
lunch consisting of a few
crackers & the Teal shot
yesterday. Then started
shooting with Henshaw
taking both Jup. & Billy.
First shot a C. Rail at the
foot of the lane. Then through
the swamp but saw nothing but
a Green Heron. Billy made a
very long point on a Snipe.
Then over to Block Island. Shot
each two Snipe and saw nearly
fifty others but they all rose
wild. Saw one wisp of twelve
Snipe all flying together & another
accompanied by a Pectoral. Saw
Cat Birds, Vir. Rails (Heard one sing)
& N. Herons. Shot four Robins
near the track. Saw two Night Hawks.
Friday, September 25, 1868.
  Cloudy all day. Rained
hard all last night
& all this forenoon.
Ther. about 50[degrees] - 60[degrees] - 
50[degrees]. Rose as usual.
After getting back
from school, had lunch
immediately and started
shooting taking Billy & my
long gun. Shot first a Coot
on the pond firing both barrels
at him. Then killed a Musk
Rat in the Glacialis. Next
tried the meadows & shot three
Snipe & two Carolina Rails without
missing a shot. Then went
up to Smith's pond and on
way down shot a Virginia
Rail & missed a Night Hawk
of which I saw numbers.
Saw L. B. Mar. Wrens & Sav.
Sparrows. Saw only four Snipe.
Measured my birds in the
evening & caught my duck
for to morrow morning.

Saturday, September 26, 1868.
  A.M. cloudy. Most of
P.M. clear. Ther. about
60[degrees] - 65[degrees] - 58[degrees]. Rose
at 3.30 A.M. & dressed myself
although it was raining
fast but no sooner had I got
out than it stopped. Had to
bale [bail] out my boat & by the time
I had got my decoys out the
day was dawning. Saw nothing
for some time, but three Wood Ducks
passing over high. Just as I was
taking in my decoy a duck, probably
a Wh. Wng. Coot came into the
pond. I sculled up to within
a long shot of him & pulled both
triggers but only wounded him badly.
The swamp maples are arrayed in
their most gorgeous colors. Got back
at 10.30 A.M. Then stuffed my Coot
(male) shot yesterday. After dinner
went up to the pond & pulled around
it seeing a Grebe & several Night
Hawks. Studied in evening.
Autumnals flying this evening
as thick as ever.
Sunday, September 27, 1868.
  Cloudy and rained
nearly all day.
Ther. about 54[degrees] - 60[degrees] - 
54[degrees]. Rose as usual
and shaved. In A.M.
attended church as
usual. After dinner
took a walk with father,
taking Jup. Heard
a Swamp Sparrow sing.
The pears (Bartlett)
are all gone, and there
are very few peaches
left. The grapes are
fast turning and if
the frost holds off for
a short time longer
they will soon ripen.
Autumnals still
abundant. Saw a
House Wren to day.

Monday, September 28, 1868.
  Clear and a beautiful
day at last. Ther.
about 60[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 65[degrees].
Rose as usual.
Had lunch as soon
as I got back from
school and then
started shooting in my
wagon with J. Russell.
Rode up to Lexington
meeting Rodgers & Frank
Low as we were passing
the Pond. Knocked a
Grey Squirrel of a stone
wall but he got away.
Then cut down a young
Ruffed Grouse at a close
cross shot but Billy pulled
most of his tail feathers out.
Got a number of wild
grapes & shot two Autumnals
for measurements.
Got back at 7.30 P.M.
Read most of the evening.
Tuesday, September 29, 1868.
  Clear but very windy
Ther. about 50[degrees] - 
60[degrees] - 50[degrees]. Rose
as usual. After
getting back from school
had lunch. Then started
shooting with H. Henshaw
in my wagon. Got out
first at the Woodcock
grounds beyond Well.
Hill. After a most
careful search Billy put
up a Cock which lit a short
distance off. I put him up
myself again & fired a long
shot at him but missed
him. Saw a Yellow Rump
& a Pig. Hawk. Then over to
the pond in Waltham but
saw nothing. H. shot a tame
pigeon & a Robin. Went into
Pout pond coming home.
Saw a Night Hawk. Walnuts
beginning to turn & swamp
maples about to lose their leaves.

Wednesday, September 30, 1868.
  A.M. clear and cold
P.M. warm, cloudy
& windy. Ther. about
42[degrees] - 60[degrees] - 60[degrees].
Rose at 3.30 A.M.
and went up to the pond.
Got out our decoys at about
5 A.M. and soon three
Black Ducks came over &
I got a female & R. Deane
another. Then shot a Com.
Coot. Then a flock of about
twenty Ruddy Ducks came
into the pond and R.
Deane & I together shot
ten of which two were stolen
& wounded many others. Fired
at a Gr. Bl. Heron. Left the
pond covered with Coots
chasing the remaining ducks.
After school began on a female
Ruddy and finished her at 6 P.M.
Then took a ride around the
pond taking Jup.
Thursday, October 1, 1868.
  Cloudy but no rain.
50[degrees] - 60[degrees] - 50[degrees].
Rose at 3.30 A.M. & went
up to the pond.
Shot two Ruddy Ducks.
In the evening cleaned
both my guns.
In P.M. took Tiger
and carried my boat
up to the pond with
Theo and then sculled
it all over the pond.

Friday, October 2, 1868.
  Cloudy & rain most of
the A.M.
Ther. 50[degrees] 62 50
Rose at 4.45 a.m. &
went up to the pond.
took my smallest
Boat & shot a Black
Duck flying firing
both barrels at
him at once.
Saw a number
of the same kind
in the P.M. went up
to the pond & put
Rowlocks into the
small boat.
Saturday, October 3, 1868.
  Cloudy & rain all
the A.M.
Ther. 50[degrees] 60[degrees] - 50[degrees].
rose at 3.30 & went up
to the pond in the rain
decoyed seven black duck
nearly in when they were
started by a boat and flew
over us, Ruth bringing down
one, which he could not find
then chased a Scoter about
the pond for some time.
Coming home shot a king-fisher
with a heavy charge thereby
hurting my hand badly.
got home at 9.30 A.M.
wet through. After which
stuffed my black duck
shot yesterday. In P.M.
went up to the pond with
R. Deane and saw the Scoter
again. A Loon seen on
the pond to day.

Sunday, October 4, 1868.
  Clear and beautiful
day. Ther. about 50 - 60 - 50.
Rose as usual and
attended church in A.M.
In P.M. rode over
to Stoneham with father
and saw six black ducks
and a lemon & white
painter.
Monday, October 5, 1868.
  Cloudy and warm.
Ther. about 55[degrees] - 60[degrees] - 
55[degrees]. Rose as usual
and walked down with
the boys. Studied as soon
as I got back from,
school. Then went
up 'to the pond' with
R. Deane and fixed
some anchors for our
ducks. Saw a Black
Duck and a Night
Hawk. Went to bed at
8.30 P.M. My hand
is beginning to heal.
transcriberNotes: Sunday, Oct 4, not written by William Brewster.

Tuesday, October 6, 1868.
  Clear but rather windy.
Ther. about 60[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 
48[degrees]. Rose at 3.30 A.M.
and went up to the
pond with Ruth Dean.
Got our ducks out
at least half an hour
before daylight. Saw
nothing during the
morning but one Black
Duck, which I fired
at as it passed high
overhead. Saw only
Charlie Chennery on the
pond.Got home to
breakfast. In P.M.
rode over to Stoneham
with father & mother
and tried to trade for
the pointer but could
not. Studied at R's in
evening. Henshaw shot
a Gr. Wing Teal.
Wednesday, October 7, 1868.
  Clear most of the day.
Ther. about 40[degrees] - 75[degrees] - 
60[degrees]. Rose as usual
and walked down
with the boys. After
school studied with
Theo. Then took Billy
& went up to 'the pond'.
Went through the
swamp and got a Snipe
& a Bittern, both flying.
Billy pointed the former
& I had to fire twice
at the latter to kill him
dead. Then started a Black
Duck & wounded him
badly but as I mistook the
trigger, I failed to get the
second barrel into him. Saw
a Tit Lark, a C. Rail & Rusties
in abundance. To bed at 9 P.M.
Saw a Phoebe & a Barn
Swallow with shattered
wing feathers. Saw several
Crossbills.

Thursday, October 8, 1868.
  A.M. clear for the
most part. P.M.
cloudy and rained
quite hard for an hour
or more. Ther. about
60[degrees] - 74[degrees] - 60[degrees].
Rose at 4 A.M. and
went up to the pond
meeting Ruth. at his gate.
Got out our decoys by
daylight but saw nothing
but a Common Coot.
A flock of fifteen Geese went
over 'the pond'. After school
studied with Theo.
Then rode over to Stoneham
with J. Croswell and
tried Dark again. Found
a number of Woodcock which
he pointed. I fired once &
[?] once but both
missed. Gave Jup. & $23.00
for the dog.Saw eight Black
Ducks & several Grass
Finches.
Friday, October 9, 1868.
  Clear and cold.
Ther. about 40[degrees] - 50[degrees] - 
45[degrees]. Rose at 4.30 A.M.
and went up to the
pond but did not
take my ducks.
Took out my large boat.
Saw numbers of Black
Ducks but did not get
a shot at any.
Looked in at the little
pond at the foot of the lane
and got a sitting shot
at a Gallinule sitting
& killed him. Another rose
at the shot and I fired at
him wounding him badly.
After school went up to the
pond with Tiger and mended
my boat. Then rode horse &
went up to the pond again
taking my gun and Dark, Shot
a Kingfisher & made a shooting
hut. Saw Pine Finches
for the first time today.

Saturday, October 10, 1868.
  Clear with an East
wind. Ther. about 40[degrees] - 
55[degrees] - 50[degrees]. Rose at
4 A.M. & meeting Ruth
at his gate went up
to 'the pond' taking
Dart. Took father's gun
and pulled across in
my small boat getting
out my decoy before
light. Heard a Mottled
Owl screeching back of my
stand & shot him. Then
a flock of a dozen Wood Ducks
came in & R. Deane got one.
At 7 A.M. went over to
Smith's pond & talked with
Frost. Then came down
through the meadows &
shot a Bl. Wn. Teal & five
Snipe. Saw a Gr. Wng. Teal
& two Coots. Got back at 2 P.M.
Then stuffed the Gallinule shot
yesterday (female). At 5 P.M.
rode up to the pond. Saw
[margin]two Tell Tales, a Vir. & Car. Rail, Crossbills, a Wh. thrt. Sp. & Gr. Bl Herons.[/margin]
Sunday, October 11, 1868.
  Clear and very warm
with a Southerly wind.
Ther. about 65[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 
60[degrees]. Rose as usual &
shaved. Attended church
in A.M. In P.M.
took a walk up to
the pond. Grapes are
nearly all ripe. Only
three or four peaches
left on one tree.
Bartlett pears & Porter
apples about finished.
Leaves on all the
trees are turning fast
& those of the swamp
maples are dropping off.

Monday, October 12, 1868.
Clear and a beautiful
day. Ther. about
50[degrees] - 60[degrees] - 50[degrees].
Rose as usual.
There was considerable
firing at the pond this
morning. After school
had my hair cut
and studied at the
Rs'. Then began on
the Mottled Owl (female)
shot Saturday & finished
him at 6 P.M.
After dinner fed
my dogs as usual
and cleaned both
my guns. Went
to bed at 9 P.M.
Tuesday, October 13, 1868.
  Clear and pleasant.
Morning rather cold.
Ther. about 42[degrees] - 
65[degrees] - 50[degrees].
Rose at 4 A.M. and
went up to the pond.
Waited some time for
Ruth. but he did not come.
Set out my duck on the
point. Soon a Com. Coot
came down to him & getting
a close shot at him I killed
him. Then a female
Surf Duck came into
the pond & Charlie Chen.
shot him. Then two
Ruddy Ducks came in , one
of which was shot & the
other wounded. Got back
to breakfast. After school
went Snipe shooting with H. Hen.
& he killed one Snipe & a
Spot Sandp. I killed
nothing. Studied in
evening.

Wednesday, October 14, 1868.
Cloudy. Rained most
of the A.M. Ther.
about 50[degrees] - 60[degrees] - 
50. Rose a 4 A.M.
and went up to the
pond. Set out my
decoy off the point.
Then pulled around
the pond & passed a
couple of Rud. Ducks in
Camb. Nook which Ch.
Chen. shot. He also
shot a Com. Coot.
Got back to breakfast.
After school studied
with Theo. Then went
up to 'the pond' with
him fishing, & caught
each a pickerel. Saw a
Fish Hawk. Got back
at 6 P.M. Went to bed
at 8.30 P.M.
Thursday, October 15, 1868.
  Cloudy and rained
most of A.M. Ther.
about 50[degrees] - 60[degrees] - 50[degrees].
Rose as usual. After
school had lunch.
Then took my gun &
Billy & went up to the
pond. Shot two Rusties.
Then saw a Com. Coot in
the swamp and fired
at him. Then finding that
the meadows were full
of Snipe, I began on them
& quickly shot five, when
it became too dark to
shoot. Billy behaved
admirably & made a
great many points.
After supper cleaned
my long gun for to-morrow.

Friday, October 16, 1868.
  Clear and a most
lovely day. Ther. about
50[degrees] - 70[degrees] - 60[degrees].
Rose at 4.30 A.M.
& went up to the pond
taking Billy. Took out
my large boat and
sculled all over the
pond. Finally shot
two Com. Coots at the
mouth of Alewife brook,
both flying. Then went
into the meadows & shot
eight Snipe without
missing but failed to kill
the ninth. Saw a Green
Heron & heard Swamp
Sparrows singing. Billy
made a number of points.
Coming home a fellow shot a
Coot at the foot of the lane.
Took the 2.30 P.M. train
for Concord & found Dan
laying tiles.
Saturday, October 17, 1868.
  Cloudy & snowed fast
all the A.M. about
four inches falling.
Ther. about 40[degrees] - 
32[degrees] - 30[degrees]. Rose at 5.30
A.M. with Dan. & taking
his boat pulled up the
river to Fairhaven bay.
Saw a Fox and fired at
him at about 100 yards
distance. Also started
a Black Duck twice.
Saw a Gr. Blue Heron.
Had to pull, all the way
back against the driving
storm & by the time we
reached home we were chilled
through. Took the 1.30 train
home. In P.M. went up
to 'the pond' where R. Deane
had just shot some tame
Moscovy Ducks of Butler's.
Studied at R's in evening.

Sunday, October 18, 1868.
  Clear but very cold
& winterish. Ther.
About 28[degrees] - 45[degrees] - 
40[degrees]. Rose as usual.
Attend church in
A.M. took a ride &
called to see R. Deane
in P.M. Leaves all dropping.
Much of the snow of
yesterday still remaining
in the fields. The
ground froze hard
last night.
Monday, October 19, 1868.
  Cloudy & rained most
of the day. Ther. about
45[degrees] - 60[degrees] - 60[degrees].
Rose at 4.30 A.M.
& went up to 'the pond'.
Went out with Ruth in
my large boat. Came across
a flock of about a dozen
Rud. Ducks in the dark
and killed one as they
rose. Got another shot
also killing one.
Russells killed two
but Ruth none.
Saw one probably an
adult nearly all white.
Got home at 7.15 A.M.
After school went up to
the pond. Took a very
long shot at a flying Green
Wing and killed him, on the
Glacialis. Got back at 6 P.M.
Uncle Albert & Minnie
came in the evening.

Tuesday, October 20, 1868.
  Clear and pleasant.
Ther. about 50[degrees] - 
65[degrees] - 50[degrees].
Rose at 4.30 A.M.
and went up to 'the
pond'. Took my little
boat & got out before Ruth.
came. He had to scull
all the morning as
somebody had stolen our
oars. Got only one, & that
a long flying shot at a
Buffle Head but killed
him. Got back in time
for breakfast. After
school studied & rode
up to 'the pond' with
Theo. & found that Pat
Skeins had taken our oars.
Came directly home &
began on my Buffle
Head. R. Deane called in
evening. Let Dart run
to day for the first time.
Wednesday, October 21, 1868.
  Cloudy. Began to rain
at 12 N. & rained
hard the rest of the day.
Ther. about 40[degrees] - 50[degrees] - 
50[degrees]. Rose at 4.30
A.M. and went up
'the pond'. Pulled across
'the pond' with Ruth. in
our large boat, towing the
small one. Tried to find
our oars but could not.
Pulled around in my
small boat & then went
over to the Glacialis but
not a gun was fired in the
neighborhood during the
morning. Ruth finally got
our oars. Got home to
breakfast. After school
studied as usual and
plucked two Ruddies &
my Teal. Cleaned my
long gun in the evening.

Thursday, October 22, 1868.
  Cloudy and rained
several times during
the day. Snowed a
little in the evening.
Ther. about 40[degrees] - 40[degrees] - 
38[degrees]. Rose as usual. 
After school had lunch.
Then went up to R.
Deane's and we made
some block with thole
pins for our large boat.
Then went up to the
pond taking our guns
and fixed on the blocks.
Pulled across the
pond together & also had
a sail. Saw three small
Geese of some kind or other
pass over 'the pond'.
Several ducks had been
seen there during the
afternoon. In evening
studied at the R's. The
leaves of most of the
trees are off.
Friday, October 23, 1868.
  Clear but cold. Ther.
about 30[degrees] - 40[degrees] - 
32[degrees]. Rose at 4.30 A.M.
and went up to 'the
pond'. I took my small
boat out while Ruth. had
the larger one. He started
a large flock of Geese from
the pond where they had
passed the night. Saw
and chased a number
of Ruddy Ducks but
did not fire a shot. Had
both my double barrells.
Heard the first Tree
Sparrow to day.
After school went
up to 'the pond' & fixed
leather in the resulting
hole & rowlocks. Went through
the meadows but saw no Snipe.
Saw an Eng. Snipe this noon
in Cambridge Port.

Saturday, October 24, 1868.
  Clear and very cold.
Ther. about 24[degrees] - 40[degrees] - 
45[degrees]. Rose at 4.30 A.M.
& went up to 'the pond'.
Got on to four Wood
Ducks before light but
as Charlie Chen. was close
behind me fired a long shot &
only wounded one which got off.
Saw numbers of ducks on the
pond. At about 10 A.M. went
over to the Glaci. & shot an old
pair of Green Wings together with
a young one. Coming back to the
pond 8 Canvas Backs lit & I
got nearly on to them when a
train started them up & I fired a
long shot (missed). Then R. Deane
got on to them & stopped two but
did not get either. Got back at 11
A.M. & after a lunch went back
to the pond. Fred. Hitt. shot a Bl.
Wing Teal, Richardson a Rff.
Grouse & I saw 9 ducks on
the pond that were unknown
to me.
[margin]Saw Brown Creepers. Saw the last Kingfisher.[/margin]
Sunday, October 25, 1868.
  A.M. clear. P.M.
cloudy. Ther. about
45[degrees] - 58[degrees] - 50[degrees].
Rose as usual. Attended
church in A.M. In
P.M. rode over to Stoneham
with father & saw Darling.
R. Deane called in
the evening & stayed
several hours.

Monday, October 26, 1868.
  A.m. cloudy & moist.
P.M. clear. Ther. about
50[degrees] - 55[degrees] - 45[degrees].
Rose at 4.30 A.M. &
getting Bill up to harness
Tiger, rode up to the
Glacialis & set out my
tame duck before light.
Nothing came in during
the morning. Heard
numbers of Snipe flying
about before light. Saw
Tit Larks & Pine Finches.
Rode over to 'the pond'.
& saw young Barker
sculling up to three
Ruddy Ducks. Got
back to breakfast. In
P.M. stuffed my pair
of Green Wings but did
not have time to set them
up. Gave two of them to
Mr. Russell for his chef
supper. I practice Dark
every evening now on holding
& carrying.
Tuesday, October 27, 1868.
  Clear and pleasant.
P.M. very windy. Ther. about
32[degrees] - 45[degrees] - 50[degrees]. Rose
at 4.30 A.M. & met R. Deane
at his gate. Took out my small
boat. Started five or six Whistlers
from the pond and as they
circled around the clearing
almost musical whistle of their
wings stealing through the air
was very impressive. Then
heard a harsh 'calae'  repeated
a number of times & found it
to be Dumb Bird (large size)
which I shot. Saw another
duck of some kind or other. Then
went over to Smith's & shot a
Com[mon] Coot. Heard a Snow Bunting.
Got back at 11 A.M. After lunch
took Tiger & Billy & tried the
woods in Lex. & Waltham &
shot a Rabbit. Saw Crow Blackbirds
& Rusties.  The R's shot a large
Hawk.

Wednesday, October 28, 1868.
Clear and pleasant.
Ther. about 60[degrees] - 65[degrees] - 
48[degrees]. Rose as usual
and did not go up
to 'the pond' as I
thought it was too warm.
Got out of school at
12 N. After eating
my lunch took Billy
and went up to 'the
pond' intending to go into the
swamps but as they said there
were Ducks on the pond I went
out in my large boat. Chased
five Dumb Birds around all
the afternoon & shot two
of them. When swimming
in security they erected their
tails & they at last took to
diving. Sailed back to the
engine house at a tremendous
rate. Drew up my small boat on
the shore for to-morrow morning
& in so doing sprained my
side badly. An unknown
[margin] bird passed over me by moonlight uttering a succession lond piercing whistles. George Barker shot 10 Dumb Birds this morning.[/margin]
Thursday, October 29, 1868.
  Clear & pleasant.
Ther. about 25[degrees] - 45[degrees] - 32[degrees].
Rose at 4.30 A.M.
& went up to the pond.
It was quite cold but
nothing came into the
pond except a flock of
six ducks, which I judge
were Golden Eyes, from
the whistling of their wings.
Then went over to the Glacialis
& saw a Black Duck.
In P.M. went over to
Smith's pond but did
not see anything.
Studied in evening.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Friday, October 30, 1868.
  Clear and cold. Ther.
about 28[degrees] - 40[degrees] - 30[degrees].
Rose at 4.30 A.M.
& went up to 'the pond'.
Pulled around in my
light boat & as nothing 
came in I went over
to the Glacialis. While
there a Ruddy Duck
came on the the pond, &
Ruth got it. After
school went up into
Lexington taking Billy.
At his first point
fired at & missed two
Rf. Grouse & a Rabbit,
all of which came out of
the same bush. Then
Billy found a Woodcock
which I fired at three
times. Got home at
6 P.M.
Saturday, October 31, 1868.
  A.M. clear & cold.
P.M. cloudy & warm.
Ther. about 22[degrees] - 40[degrees] - 50[degrees].
Rose at 4.45 A.M. &
rode up to 'the pond', tying
Tiger at the water works.
Stayed out till 8A.M.
but nothing came in.
Then took Ruth up into
Lex. & Waltham. He shot
a Crow from  the wagon, & I
shot a female Quail on Rock
Meadow. Then over to Hurman's
pond & saw large numbers
of ducks. Fired at a Gr. Wng.
Teal & a Rf. Grouse Saw a 
flock of Snow Bunts, also
Rusties, Fox Colors, Marsh
Hawks & Robins. Got home
at 2 P.M. & shot two Pine
Grosbeaks in the yard.
In P.M. plucked some
ducks for dinner.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Sunday, November 1, 1868.
  Cloudy & rained nearly
all the time. Ther.
about 60[degrees] - 60[degrees] - 
50[degrees]. Rose as usual
& shaved. Spent
most of the day in
the house and
did not go to church.
R. Deane called in
P.M. & J. Nichols
in the evening.
The leaves are all
off, but the grass
is still quite green.
Monday, November 2, 1868.
  Cloudy & rained
most of A.M. In P.M.
it snowed hard for
some time. Ther. about
34[degrees] - 38[degrees] - 34[degrees].
Rose as usual.
After school (which
began to day at 8.45
A.M.) had lunch.
Then went up to the
R's & studied. After
dinner at 5 P.M.
stuffed the Quail,
shot Saturday.
Went to bed at 10 P.M.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Tuesday, November 3, 1868.
  A.M. cloudy &
snowed a good deal.
P.M. clear & pleasant.
Ther. about 32[degrees] - 40[degrees] - 
30[degrees]. Rose as usual.
Walked down to
school through the
Square where the
election was going on.
After school had
lunch and cleaned
both my guns.
Then went up to the
Rs' & studied till 5
P.M. Then rode up to
'the pond' & baled out
my small boat which
was nearly full of
water. In evening stuffed
the Pine Grosbeak (young
male) shot Saturday.
Went to bed at 10.30 P.M.
Saw a Night Heron probably
the last.
Wednesday, November 4, 1868.
  Clear and a beautiful
day. Ther. about 26[degrees] - 
50[degrees] - 34[degrees]. Rose at
4.30 A.M. Got Bill up
& had Tiger harnessed.
Rode up to the Sherman's
pond taking Billy &
getting there just as it
was getting light.
Set out my duck but
he would not quack
decently. Foled two ducks
probably Gr. Wn. Teal nearly
within shot, but they
would come no nearer.
Got back to Breakfast after
having a glorious ride.
After school took a ride
with R. Deane, in his buggy
through Waverly & Belmont.
Then studied with Theo.
At 7.30 P.M. went up
to Dr. Wyman's to see "The
Spirit of '76" & a farce.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Thursday, November 5, 1868.
  Cloudy & rained
most of P.M.
Ther. about 40[degrees] - 50[degrees] - 
38[degrees]. Rose as usual.
Walked down to school
with the boys.
Refrained from whispering
& accordingly got
dismissed an hour
early. After having
lunch went up to
'the pond' with Theo.
Pulled across in my
small boat and then
as it began to rain, got
under the shelter of
an ice house, & stayed there
with Theo over an hour.
Then went over to Smith's
pond but saw nothing.
Studied in evening. The
Sparrows exceedingly
numerous. Saw another
Pine Grosbeak in  our
yard.
Friday, November 6, 1868.
Clear & a lovely day.
Ther. about 38[degrees] - 50[degrees] - 40[degrees].
Rose at 5 A.M. & went
up to "the pond'. Pulled
about all the morning
in my small boat but
did not see a duck of
any description. Coming
home shot a Hairy
Woodpecker & saw a flock
of six or seven White Winged
& Common Crossbills
of both sexes. After school
had lunch. Then took
Dart, & rode up to Sherman's
pond with Tiger. Set
out a wooden Teal for
to morrow morning.
Then crept on to two Green
Wings & after missing the sitting
shot, killed a young male flying
off. Dart fetched him in.
On the way up fired a splendid
shot at a Red Tailed Hawk
from the wagon. The teal
[margin] made several very [?] noises.[/margin].

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Saturday, November 7, 1868.
  Clear and a most
lovely day. Ther. about
24[degrees] - 50[degrees] - 24[degrees].
Rose at 4 A.M. &
after getting Tiger
harnessed rode up to
Sherman's pond. Saw
a mink in Waverly.
At the pond a Black Duck
went out as I approached.
Set out my ducks but
as nothing came in
sight, I stalked
two Ruddy Ducks feeding
over the shore & killed one
which Billy retrieved. Saw
nearly an acre of Rusty & Crow
Blackbirds, also two Rf. Grouse
& a Woodcock. Coming home saw
Crossbills & a Yellow Rump.
Shot a female Red Tailed Hawk
from the wagon. Got home at
10 A.M. Spent the rest of the
day in stuffing him. At 9
P.M. finished him & studied at Rs.
Sunday, November 8, 1868.
  Cloudy & rained several
times. Ther. about 40[degrees] - 
50[degrees] - 40[degrees]. Rose as
usual  & shaved. In A.M.
attended church with
my cousin Clara. In
P.M. read & took a
walk with J. Nichols.
Took tea at at his house
in the evening.
After I got home wrote
to Dan and C. Carter.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Monday, November 9, 1868.
  Cloudy & rained most
of the time. Ther. about
40[degrees] - 45[degrees] - 40[degrees].
Rose as usual.
Rode down to school
in the car as my
back has troubled me
lately very badly.
Also rode home from
school. After lunch
went up to the Rs' &
studied at the P.M. In evening
stuffed the Hairy
Woodpecker (female)
shot last Friday (6th).
Tuesday, November 10, 1868.
  Cloudy & rained all day.
Ther. about 40[degrees] - 50[degrees] - 
40[degrees]. Rose as usual
& rode down to school
although my back was
much better to day.
Also rode home.
After luch picked
the Gr. Wn. Teal shot
Friday last, & R. Deane
called in & stayed
till dinner time.
After supper went
up to the Rs' & studied
all the evening.
The leaves are now
all off, & the aspect of
the country desolate in
the extreme.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Wednesday, November, 11, 1868.
Cloudy & rained
nearly  all day.
Ther. about 42[degrees] - 
50[degrees] - 34[degrees]. Rose
as usual and shaved.
Walked down to
school. After getting
back from school had
lunch as usual.
Then made some
varnish for coloring
birds feet & legs.
In evening studied
at the Rs'.
Thursday, November 12,  1868.
  Clear but very
windy. Ther. about
40[degrees] - 45[degrees] - 30[degrees].
Rose as usual.
Coming home from
school dropped in at
Lyceum Hall & saw
the two double guns
(Ellis breach & muzzle loaders).
Took three shares in
them. In P.M. studied
at Rs'. In the evening
went down to the
Hall with mother &
Clara and saw the
tableaus. Got home
at about 11 P.M.

Friday, November 13, 1868.
  Clear & a most lovely
day. Ther. about 24[degrees] - 
40[degrees] - 30[degrees]. Rose as usual.
On the way to school while
passing the Bacheldor's place,
heard a strange cry (kuk
kr-kr-kr-kr-kra-a-a), &
on looking saw the author
of the sound, a genuine Canada
Woodpecker (Picus Canadensis
of Audubon). In a few
moments a Shrike attacked
him, & drove him some distance.
After school took Tiger in
father's buggy & picking
up  Farrar took a ride
up through Lex. & back
through Waltham.
Saw about eight Common
Crossbills feeding on a
stuble field & hopping about
like so many Sparrows.
Saturday, November 14, 1868.
  Clear and very warm
for the season. Ther. about
30[degrees] - 60[degrees] - 30[degrees].
Rose at 5 A.M. Got Bill
up & had Tiger harnessed.
Rose up to Sherman's pond
getting there by sunrise.
Saw large quantities of
meteors, some of them very
large & splendid. Shot a
Lesser Redpoll. Saw R. Deane
with his team. He shot his
first Woodcock to day. Then rode
over to the  turnpike & shot a
Gray Squirrell. Saw two Pine
Grosbeaks. Got back at 10. Took
the 11 A.M. train for Concord.
Went out with Dan & each
of us, shot a Squirrell. D. also
shot a Hairy Woodpecker.
Took the 6.50 train home,
& found Bill waiting at
Porter's.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Sunday, November 15, 1868.
  A.M. cloudy. P.M.
clear. Ther. about
40[degrees] - 45[degrees] - 40[degrees].
Rose  as usual & shaved.
Attended church in
A.M. In P.M. took
a walk up around
''the pond'. with R. Deane.
The Gulls come into
the pond regularly,
now, every morning.
Read & studied most
of evening.
Monday, November 16, 1868.
  Clear and a beautiful
day. Ther about 30[degrees] - 
40[degrees] - 26[degrees]. Rose as
usual. After school
rode up through
Belmont in my open
buggy. Saw a Red Tailed
Hawk sitting in a field
near the roadside, &
riding through a gate into
the field, got a long flying
shot  and killed it.
Then beat the neighboring
thickets for Woodcock but
found none. Then rode over
Well. hill & tried again.
Billy found & pointed a Rf.
Grouse, but it rose out of
range. He also started a
rabbit. Came home by Smith's
pond where I saw two ducks. Tied
my horse & got a fellow to paddle
me after them but they dove
out of range. Fired a long
shot at one of them.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Tuesday, November 17, 1868.
  Cloudy & cold. Ther.
about 26[degrees] - 34[degrees] - 30[degrees].
Rose as usual.
After school took my
shooting wagon &
Billy & rode over to
Smith's pond. Then
shot one of Frost's
decoy ducks, taking
it for a wild one, as
I could only see
its head. Saw a
Ruddy Duck in the
pond but could not
get a shot at it.
Got back, at 5.20 P.M.
In evening studied at
the Rs'. The Glacialis
is frozen over.
Wednesday, November 18, 1868.
  Cloudy & rained
hard all day.
Ther. about 40[degrees] - 
40[degrees] - 34[degrees]. Rose as usual.
Walked with Theo & got
late. Rode home from
school as it was raining
hard. Then made a
stand for my Hawk
(shot Monday) & stuffed
him finishing at
8 P.M. Then studied
at the Rs'.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Thursday, November 19, 1868.
  Cloudy but did not
rain. Cleared off at
sunset. Ther. about
30[degrees] - 40[degrees] - 34.
Rose at 6 A.M. and
went up to 'the pond'.
Baled out my small
boat and sculled
about all the morning
but did not see any
thing but a Crow. Got
back to breakfast.
Recited the first three
hours, & got dismissed.
After eating lunch rode
up to 'the pond' taking
Theo. Tied Tiger & went
out after a flock of about
fifty Gulls but did not
get a shot at them.
Then rode over to Smith's & paid
Frost. Fired at an adult
Ruddy Duck, which Frost
finished & gave to me.
Friday, November 20, 1868.
  Clear and pleasant.
Ther. about 30[degrees] - 45[degrees] - 
30[degrees]. Rose as usual.
Recited the first three
hours & got dismissed
at recess. After eating
lunch, took Tiger
and rode up to 'the
pond'. Tried to get a
shot at a number of
Gulls that were sitting
on 'the pond' but they
all went out. Fired
at a Crow and broke
the forward trigger of
my long gun. Rode
over to Smith's pond
but did not see any
thing. Had to touch
off my gun with a
match. Got home in
time for dinner. After
dinner R. Deane called
& a little later Dan came
in from Concord.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Saturday, November 21, 1868.
  Alternately cloudy
& clear. Ther. about
28[degrees] - 35[degrees] - 30[degrees].
Rose as usual.
After breakfast harnessed
up Tiger and took
Dan down to John
Hopkinson's where he
got his gun. Then rode
up to 'the pond' and took
a sail. Then rode up
through Belmont & Dan
bought a Long Eared 
Owl for 25 cts. Then
kept on up to Sherman's
pond, but did not
fire a shot during the
day. Had lunch at
about 1 P.M. & built
a fire. Got home
at 5 P.M. In evening
I stuffed the male Dumb
Bird shot the other day &
Dan skinned his Owl.
Sunday, November 22, 1868.
  Cloudy but rather warm.
Ther. about 30[degrees] - 45[degrees] - 
30[degrees]. Rose as usual
and shaved. Attended
church in A.M. with
Dan. In P.M. took
a walk with J. Nichols.
R. Deane called in
evening & took tea with
us.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Monday, November 23, 1868.
  Clear and a most
beautiful day.
Ther. about 28[degrees] - 
45[degrees] - 30[degrees]. Rose
as usual. After
breakfast fired twice
at my pigeons flying
over and wounded
one of them badly. Then
caught my poorest decoy
and took him up to
'the pond' & Dan & I each
taking a boat let him
out and after firing about
a dozen times at him
I finished him. Then
went over to Smith's
pond but did not see
anything. Got back at 3
P.M. After eating a lunch
took Tiger in my wagon & with
Dan set a trap for a rabbit &
another for a mink in the
pine swamp. Met Ruth as he
was on horseback. In A.M. saw
a Winter Wren & several Gulls on the pond.
Tuesday, November 24, 1868
  Clear and warm
with a Southerly wind.
Ther. about 28[degrees] - 45[degrees] - 
35[degrees]. Rose as usual.
After breakfast had
Tiger harnessed and
set off. Stopped first at
the fields near 'the pond'
& had a "pigeon shoot",
killing six out of eight,
each three. Went to my
traps but found nothing
caught. Heard some Pin. Gros.
Then kept on into Waltham
& started a 'bevy' of about a
dozen Quail. Followed them
up all day & I killed two
only. Fired five shots at them.
Billy made four brilliant
points, & did not run into
a single bird. Dan fired one
shot at a single bird. Saw  a
Gray Squirrel. Got back at
5 P.M.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Wednesday, November 25, 1868.
  A.M. clear & remarkably
warm, & sunny for
the season. Ther. about
30[degrees] - 40[degrees] - 30[degrees].
Rose at 6.30 A.M. with
Dan. Called Bill up,
& had Tiger harnessed.
Rode directly up to
Waltham & tied our
horse. We soon found
our bevy of Quail on
a Southerly hillside,
& I stopped one as they
went up. Billy got
two more points, but
I missed one, & did not
fire at the other. Then
shot two handsome male
White Wing Grosbills, one
of which I gave to Dan.
Had lunch at 12 N. Afterwards
shot a young Pine Grosbeak
& a Blue Jay. After dinner
took Dan up to Porter's station
where he left for home.
Thursday, November 26, 1868.
  Rainy as Thanksgiving
always  is. Ther. about
40[degrees] - 40[degrees] - 40[degrees].
Rose as usual.
After breakfast had
the General harnessed in
the covered buggy &
rode as far as Brighton
with J. Nichols, when
it commenced to rain
so hard that we were
obliged to turn back.
After dinner rode over
to see Mr. Barnes in my
open buggy. When
I got home found R.
Deane in the barn
& talked with him for
some time. Read most
of the evening.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Friday, November 27,1868.
  Clear but very windy.
Ther. about 38[degrees] - 40[degrees] - 
30[degrees]. Rose at 6 A.M.
& went up to 'the
pond'. The wind was
blowing a perfect gale,
but the Gulls got there
by sunrise. Fired
one shot only & that
a very long one, at a
Gull. Saw several
Gulls on the Glacialis.
Got back to breakfast.
Then went into Boston
with R. Deane. Called
to see Samuels first.
Then selected some cloth
for a new suit, at J. NIchols
store. Then went through
Quancy Market, down
to Sam Turner's, to Beads,
Lovel's, & finally to Copeland's
where we had some
oysters. Got out of Boston
at 5 P.M. Read most of evening.
Saturday, November 28, 1868.
  Clear and warm.
Ther. about 24[degrees] - 45
30[degrees]. Rose as usual.
After breakfast R. Deane
called & I went off with
him in his buggy.
Rode over to Stoneham
& called first to see the
elder Sprague, but he
was not at home. Then
called at his son's & talked
with him for some time.
Then rode up through
Stoneham & across towards
Winchester. Tied the horse
& I shot a female Wh. Wng
Grosbill but spoilt her.
Came back through Arlington.
Stopped at 'the pond' & found a
hole knocked in the bottom of
our large boat. Got home at
3 P.M. Took bill & the tip cart,
& got my small boat home.
Studied in evening.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Sunday, November 29, 1868.
  Alternately cloudy &
clear. Ther. about 36[degrees] - 
40[degrees] - 34[degrees]. Rose as
usual. Attended
church in A.M.
as usual. Read most
of evening. Snowed a
little last night.
Monday, November 30, 1868.
  Cloudy & very chilly.
Ther. about 26[degrees] - 40[degrees] - 
33[degrees]. Rose as usual.
Walked down with Theo.
& called at Dalton's.
Went into Boston from
school. Called first at
13 Com. Wharf to see about
having a boat made, but
they could do nothing for me.
Then called at Cragin's,
Broad St. & looked over
his boats but decided
on nothing. Took an ice
cream at Copelands.
Got out at 5 P.M. After
dinner studied at the
Rs'. In evening went
down to the High School
Debating Club & heard
Licence & Prohibition.
Got back at 9.30 P.M.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Tuesday, December 1, 1868.
Cloudy all day.
Morning broke snowing
fast & it continued
snowing until 12 N.
when it ceased, about
two inches having fallen.
Ther. about 24[degrees] - 26[degrees] - 
20[degrees]. Rose at 6.30 A.M.
and went up to 'the pond'.
Walked up along the
shore as far as Barker's
cove, but as I saw nothing
came home. After
school had lunch as
usual. Then took Billy
and rode up to Waltham.
Beat for the Quail that
I found last week, but
was unable to come across
them. Got back at 5.30
P.M. Saw several Redpolls
this morning. Studied
at the Rs' in the evening.
Wednesday, December 2, 1868.
  Clear but very windy.
Ther. about 18[degrees] - 30[degrees] - 
16[degrees]. Rose as usual
and shaved. Walked
down to school with
the boys. Went home 
with Henshaw after
school & took lunch
with him. Looked
over his collection of
shells, and then went
out on the railroad
with him, but did
not see any thing, and
as it was very cold &
windy, we came back.
Rode up in the car
getting home at about
4.15 P.M. In evening studied
at the Rs'. Went to bed
at 10 P.M. There was
skating on Dr. Worcester's
pond.

exportComment: Fully transcribed by Grahame Parsons. Exported on 02-May-2015 from DigiVol (http://volunteer.ala.org.au)
occurrenceRemarks:
Thursday, December 3, 1868.
  Clear and a beautiful
day. Ther. about
18[degrees] - 40[degrees] - 28[degrees].
Rose as usual.
After school R. Deane
called in. Then 
Farrar called & I went
up to the Glacialis
skating, with him.
The ice was almost
perfectly smooth, &
quite strong. There
were there perhaps thirty
